[Italics denote Valyrian speech]

Â 

The days that followed after the invitation was sent to Dragonstone were filled with anxiousness. Queen Alicent had no choice but to tell Levana as she might wonder about the presence of Syrax in the Dragonpit

"Is my mother really coming?"

Queen Alicent nodded with a small smile as Levana was dressed by Galatea. The young princess' eyes brightened up as she clapped her hands in joy.

"Will she bring my brothers, Your Grace?" Levana asked but unfortunately, the queen shook her head.

"There is an important matter that your grandsire and I must discuss with your mother," Queen Alicent stated, "and for that, I ask you to stay away from the Great Hall."

"I would rather she be there."

Both females turned to the door to see King Viserys standing by it, "since the matter does concern her."

"Me, grandsire?"

Queen Alicent shook her head, "she doesn't need to be there to witness such a thing."

"She will be there by the request of the king," King Viserys smiled at his granddaughter before turning his back, "she and Rhaenyra need to discuss this as well."

With that, the king began to walk away from Levana's chambers just as the princess hopped off from the dressing stool that she stood on. The Queen looked at Levana with a warm smile and stroked her hair.

"Whatever comes out of today, young princess," Queen Alicent began, "your presence in the Red Keep has made it more lively and Aemond isn't the only one who thinks so."

Levana smiled at the queen and wrapped her arms around the older female's waist, "thank you, Queen Alicent," she began, "for being kind to me and for being my mother."

Queen Alicent looked down at her before gesturing for Galatea to finish her preparations. The queen left the room shortly after, leaving the princess and her handmaiden to their own devices as Levana took a seat in front of her vanity.

"Princess," Galatea began, "if given the chance today, would you return to Dragonstone?"

Levana looked at her handmaiden through the mirror and thought for a while before shrugging slightly. Galatea braided the princess' hair into an intricate bun as the latter sat in silence, resigning to play with the hairbrush in her hands.

"Why do you think my mother left me in High Tide?"

"Princess, it's not my place."

"And yet you ask me if I would return to Dragonstone."

Galatea bowed her head in apology as she finished the princess' bun and placed a golden headband on her head. Levana tilted her head slightly at the sight of the headband and turned to her handmaiden, "this isn't mine."

Galatea smiled, "it's a gift from the Queen."

The princess nodded before standing up from her chair and walking out of her room with Galatea in tow. She was headed to the library when she was stopped by Ser Westerling.

"Princess Rhaenyra has arrived, Your Grace," he stated as Levana's eyes brightened up in excitement, she rushed past the knight to head to the stables when Ser Westerling managed to catch up with her and shook his head.

"King Viserys and Queen Alicent request that you only see Princess Rhaenyra at the Grand Hall," Ser Westerling stated, "my apologies, Princess Levana."

The princess' smile quickly turned into a frown when she gave the knight a nod and retreated to the library. She was disappointed that she couldn't even greet her mother but if it was what her grandparents thought best, she would have to respect it.

Levana found herself in the company of her books once more. She was allowed free time to read in the library without the Septa giving her lessons. This was her favorite time of the day - when she could just appreciate the silence that surrounded her.

"Eva?"

Levana looked up from her books to see Aemond. The princess waved at him and gestured for him to join her to which the prince gladly accepted.

"Aren't you supposed to see your mother today?" Aemond asked, taking a seat beside Levana as the princess positioned the book so that they could share it.

"I was told to wait here until someone came for me," Levana sighed, "I wanted to greet her when she arrived but Ser Westerling told me that I must wait until I am summoned."

The prince shrugged as he looked down at what the princess was reading and sighed, "this again, Eva?"

Levana giggled, not because of the prince's comment but because of the nickname that he had decided to give her because he wanted to give her one that was different from what her brothers' called her.

"It's my favorite book, Aemond."

"Visenya and Rhaenys Targaryen, as always," Aemond looked at the book again and read through some of the text. There was silence between the two as they read the book until Aemond decided to break it with a question.

"Will you return to Dragonstone?"

Levana turned to him and thought for a while. In all honesty, she didn't know how to respond because she also didn't know what to say. She's been away from her family for months and while she did want to go back, she feared that she might've become distant from them.

She wouldn't know how to adjust to life with them again.

"We'll cross that bridge when we get there,"Â Levana smiled,Â "don't worry, if I do return to Dragonstone, I will write to you."

Aemond frowned,Â "it will be lonely again once you leave."

"Aemond,"Â Levana chuckled,Â "don't think that I'm going to leave yet, I haven't spoken to my mother yet."

Just as Aemond was to respond, the doors opened to reveal Queen Alicent with Ser Cole in tow.

"Levana," The Queen called as the two children stood up from the table, "it's time."

Levana nodded and bid her farewell to Aemond before walking toward the queen.

"Can I come?" Aemond asked as Queen Alicent shook her head, "this is a matter for Levana and her alone to witness."

With that, the Queen left the library with Ser Cole and Levana in tow. Aemond, on the other hand, decided that he would still try and sneak into the Grand Hall.

Aemond didn't want to see Levana leave but he didn't want her to have to go through this alone either.

â€œItâ€™s time, princess,â€ Ser Westerling stated as Levana gave him a nod. She took a deep breath as the large doors of the Grand Hall began to open.Â 

â€œPrincess Levana of Houses Targaryen and Velaryon, the second in line to inherit the Iron Throne.â€Â

â€œAna!â€

â€œWe appreciate your presence, Princess Rhaenyra though I do remember requesting that you come alone,â€ Queen Alicent looked towards the young boys beside the older princess who smiled slightly.Â 

â€œThey wanted to see their older sister,â€ Rhaenyra stated, â€œand I was not about to deprive them of such."Â 

"You had hoped to use them to sway Levana to return to Dragonstone," Queen Alicent accused, "didn't you?"Â

ã€ğŸğŸ‘ã€‘

Levana sat in her chambers, waiting for her mother to come when Aemond burst through the door. The princess looked at the young boy with an amused expression as he marched towards her.

"Don't leave, Eva."

"Aemond, I'm not going anywhere," Levana stated, "you're not supposed to be in here."

"I know," Aemond responded, "I just don't want to see you leave."

"You need not worry because the king has barred Levana from leaving King's Landing."

The two children turned towards the door where Rhaenyra stood, her hands folded across her chest.

"Prince Aemond," Rhaenyra chuckled, "why is it that I always seem to catch you in my daughter's chambers?"

Aemond looked at Levana for a short while before giving her a nod and walking out of the room. Rhaenyra watched as the prince left before closing the door behind her and facing her daughter with a sad smile.

"Did Grandsire really forbid me from leaving?" Levana asked as her mother nodded.

"Maybe it is for the best," Rhaenyra said as she sat beside her daughter. Levana moved closer to her mother and leaned her head on her shoulder.

"You must hate me."

"I think that is too much of a strong emotion for me to feel, mother," Levana responded. She was young and hate was an emotion that she was yet to fully understand. Levana might have a hint of what it felt like but she felt like it wasn't enough.

"Why did it take you long to retrieve me, mother?" Levana asked, "do you not want me anymore?"

The question made Rhaenyra tear up as she wrapped an arm around her, pulling her closer.

"It took me long because I had to make sure that we were settled before I could ask Lord Corlys and Princess Rhaenys to escort you to Dragonstone."

"I waited, mother," Levana began to cry, "I felt so alone."

Rhaenyra's heart broke as her daughter sobbed in her arms. She stroked her daughter's hair, holding one hand in hers. She noticed the ring that Levana wore and lifted her hand.

"Did your father give this to you?" Rhaenyra asked as Levana looked at the ring and nodded.

"He gave it to me the night that he died," Levana explained, "he said that it was very important to him."

Rhaenyra smiled, "this ring once belonged to Ser Joffrey Lonmouth," she explained as she observed her daughter, "he was a very important person to your father."

Levana marveled at the ring. She didn't know the reason why the ring was important to her father but at the very least, she now knew what it meant.

"If I am barred from leaving King's Landing," Levana began, "will you at least visit me with Jace, Luke, and Joff?"

Rhaenyra nodded, "we will try to visit often."

"I don't want my brothers to be distant from me," Levana sighed, "I want to be there for them too."

The older princess wrapped her daughter in a tight embrace and kissed the top of her head, "do not be distant from me either, my love."

Levana nodded, "yes mother."

"We will come for your Name Day," Rhaenyra smiled,Â "it will be a celebration to remember."

Levana smiled at her mother and nodded again, she fiddled with her fingers as the silence enveloped the both of them before the older princess asked, "have they been hospitable to you here?"

"Yes, they have!" Levana said excitedly, "the Septa provides me with lessons, I get to spend time in the library, and the Queen also spends time teaching me!"

"The Queen?" Rhaenyra raised a brow, "she spends time with you?"

"Yes mother," Levana responded, "she also reads to me and Helaena sometimes but not always because she often says that she has to deal with Aegon."

The part about Aegon did not surprise Rhaenyra as she knew her younger half-brother to be somewhat of a troublemaker but the fact that the Queen was spending time with her daughter made her wonder if there was an ulterior motive behind it.

"What else does Queen Alicent teach you, Levana?"

Levana shrugged, "sometimes it's history, sometimes religion, but sometimes she just reads to me."

"She doesn't mention me or anyone else from the family?" Rhaenyra asked as Levana shook her head.

"The Queen often tells me stories about the King and Aegon when he was growing up but never you or anyone else, mother."

Rhaenyra smiled slightly. At the very least, she knew that Alicent wasn't manipulating her own child against her.

"Mother," Levana hopped off the bed, "would you like to go around the castle with me?"

Rhaenyra nodded before standing up, "show me the places where you often spend your time in."

Levana excitedly nodded before taking her mother's hand in hers and marching out of her room. While there were things that boggled Rhaenyra's mind, she would have to wait until she got back to Dragonstone to address some of the more compelling ones.

For now, she would spend time with her daughter whom she hasn't seen in months.

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Saying farewell to Levana was, in truth, the hardest thing for Rhaenyra. She didn't have to do it the first time much to Daemon's insistence because the latter knew that it would be hard for both the princess'.

But now, Rhaenyra knew the pain of it. The crying of her sons also did not help when they boarded the boat to Dragonstone and Levana stood alongside Ser Westerling by the docks. Her daughter was barred from returning to Dragonstone and as Rhaenyra put it, it would probably be for the best.

She knew that Daemon was not particularly fond of her daughter and she was yet to find out why.

Upon arriving in Dragonstone, Rhaenyra summoned Daemon to the library - she had many questions and she wanted answers to all of them.

"Rhaenyra," Daemon called as he entered the library, "you're back."

"Where are Levana's letters?" Rhaenyra asked outright, "have you been hiding my daughter's letters from me?"

Daemon smirked, "I told you that the sooner you remove the bond with Levana, the easier it would be for you."

"She's my daughter, Daemon!" Rhaenyra raised her voice, "she came from me and she is my heir."

"Your daughter to a man that you never loved."

"I loved Laenor," Rhaenyra interjected, "it was not the love that I might've had for you but I loved him and I love Levana."

"It's only a matter of time before the Greens manipulate her, Rhaenyra."

"She's not even ten!"

"She's easier to manipulate at this age!"

"You did this on purpose, didn't you?" Rhaenyra asked, "you wanted to separate Levana from me so you would have easier access to the throne."

Daemon chuckled, "you haven't even named an heir, Rhaenyra."

"I thought it was obvious who was going to be my heir," Rhaenyra responded, "Levana is my firstborn and my rightful heir."

"Of course," Daemon laughed, "extend to her the same courtesy that your father did to you."

"I will not have my children fighting over the throne, Daemon."

"Who says there would be a fight?" Daemon asked, "declare Jacaerys as your heir and Levana can inherit Driftmark."

"Lord Corlys and Princess Rhaenys would never agree because they know that Levana is my heir."

The prince raised a brow, "that's it?"

"What do you mean, that's it?"

"The Targaryen bloodline ends with your Velaryon daughter?"

"Levana is marrying into House Targaryen," Rhaenyra stated, "the children that she is to have with Aemond will inherit the Targaryen name."

Daemon could only watch his wife in amusement.

"You think that Aemond is going to act upon a childhood betrothal when he comes of age?" Daemon asked.

"I know enough that boys will turn into men and when they do, their desires change."

Rhaenyra glared at her husband before walking past him, "give me my daughter's letters," she hissed before leaving the library.

Daemon watched as Rhaenyra's figure disappeared into the halls before looking at the fire and chuckling to himself.

"Unless you can revive paper from flames," Daemon smiled, "there's no way you're getting those letters."

ã€ğŸğŸ’ã€‘

Time was, in many ways, an enemy to most. However, to Princess Levana, it was everything but that.

The princess stood on her dressing stool as Galatea and the other handmaidens fussed over the dresses that she would have to choose from for her Name Day. On her right, the Queen sat with her hands folded on her lap, observing the princess as she chose her dresses.

King Visersys was adamant that Princess Levana be given aÂ grandÂ celebration. Invitations were sent a month in advance so all those invited would be able to prepare for it adequately.

The celebration happened in a span of seven days. There was a hunt that spanned the first four days, a tourney on the fifth day, a small festival on the sixth day, and on the final day, there would be a grand feast.

This was the night of the feast that would then lead to the gazing of the Harvest Moon - it had been a family tradition to gather at the Godswood to gaze at the moon as it was at its highest during the night of Levana's Name Day.

For her tenth Name Day, the king wanted everyone to be able to gaze at the beauty of the moon - just as they were to gaze upon the beauty of his granddaughter.

"Levana, my child, this is the seventh dress," Queen Alicent stated as Levana puffed her cheeks before looking at all the dresses that were laid out on her bed.

"Do none of them really suit your taste?" Queen Alicent asked as Levana nodded shyly. With a small sigh, the Queen gestured for the handmaidens to fetch the other dresses made for the Princess.

"Levana, the feast will begin soon and we can't spend the entire day choosing a dress."

"What is Aemond wearing, Your Grace?" Levana asked, "if I cannot choose, I will choose one that would match him."

Queen Alicent smiled, "Levana, he is supposed to match with you," she responded, "it's your Name Day."

"Why not a sea green color?" Queen Alicent suggested, "to match with your Velaryon heritage."

Levana thought for a while. It was a color that her father always wore.

"Do we have a dress in gold?" Levana asked, "I know Grandsire would be wearing something of the sort!"

Just as Queen Alicent was about to stand to check on the dresses, Galatea came rushing in with a gold dress in hand. Levana's eyes widened at the sight and hopped off her dressing stool to approach her handmaiden who held out the dress to the princess with a smile.

"Where did this come from?" Queen Alicent asked as Levana took the dress from Galatea and stood in front of the mirror.

"It came from Princess Rhaenys, my Queen," Galatea began, "she said it was a dress that she had made for the princess."

Queen Alicent took a look at the dress and furrowed her brows. It was familiar to her but she couldn't seem to remember where she had seen it before.

"Can I please wear this?" Levana asked, "will Aemond be able to match if I wore this?"

Queen Alicent nodded, "I believe he does have attire of the same color."

Levana smiled brightly as she got back up on her dressing stool and held the dress out, "I would like to wear this dress, please!"

Queen Alicent took one look at the younger girl and nodded with a smile. She then looked towards Galatea, "please make sure that the princess is ready soon, I'll go see my son."

Galatea bowed her head as the Queen walked out of the room. Galatea turned towards Levana and noticed that the little girl was gone from her dressing stool. The dress was on the bed but the princess was nowhere to be found.

"Princess Levana!"

Galatea ran towards the bathroom to find the princess but she wasn't there. Rushing back into the room, she noticed that the princess was crouched by one of the couches with her knees to her chest.

"Princess, we have to get you ready."

Levana turned to Galatea and shook her head.

"Princess, you heard the Queen, the feast will begin soon."

Galatea held her hand out for the princess but the latter refused. Instead, Levana stood up and made a run for the bath, closing the door behind her and locking it.

"Princess!"

Galatea knocked frantically on the door but the princess didn't respond.

"Princess Levana, please tell me what's wrong!"

"Please leave me alone!"

The handmaiden kept knocking and urging the princess to leave the bath but the younger female was adamant to stay inside. The commotion had caught the attention of the princess' sworn protector who came rushing into the room.

"Princess Levana," Ser Westerling called from outside the bath, "please open the door."

"No!" Levana shouted in response.

Galatea and Ser Westerling continued to try and urge the princess to remove herself from the bath but the younger female was adamant to stay inside. The two would continue to urge the princess to leave the bath but it was to no avail.

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

The festivities for the feast began without a hitch. The lords and ladies were introduced and seated before the doors opened to reveal the King and the Queen along with their children.

King Viserys of House Targaryen, the First of His Name, King of the Andals, the Rhoynar, and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms Protector of the Realm, Prince of Dragonstone

The lords and the ladies stood up to address the King and his family as they walked to the table at the end of the hall.

Queen Alicent Hightower and their children, Prince Aegon and Princess Helaena along with the Hand of the King.

The family continued to walk towards the table before taking the seats and for the doors to open again to reveal Princess Rhaenys and Lord Corlys.

Â 

Lord Corlys Velaryon, Lord of the Tides, and the Master of Driftmark. Alongside his Lady Wife, the Princess Rhaenys Targaryen, and Princess Baela Targaryen.

Â 

The Velaryons made their way to the table as the doors would continue to open to reveal Rhaenyra's family this time. While the crowd continued to cheer for the arrival of the princess, the royal family was not as excited about their arrival.

Â 

Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen, heir to the Iron Throne, and Prince Daemon Targaryen, the future King Consort along with their children, Princes Jacaerys and Lucerys Velaryon, and Princess Rhaena Targaryen.

Â 

Rhaenyra and her family took their place on the table; the princess nodded towards her family to which the king reciprocated with a nod of acknowledgment. The family remained standing as the doors would open again to finally reveal Prince Aemond standing alone.

Queen Alicent looked at the prince with worry and made her way toward Aemond.

"Where's Levana?" Queen Alicent whispered as she looked around. The Queen was shocked to see Galatea frantically running towards the hall.

"Where's the Princess?" Queen Alicent asked as Galatea took a deep breath, pointing to the direction of the princess's room. By instinct, Queen Alicent ran in the direction of Levana's room where Ser Westerling was still knocking on the door, trying to ease the princess into coming out.

"My Queen," Ser Westerling addressed Queen Alicent who rushed into the room.

"Princess Levana locked herself inside the bath," Ser Westerling stated, "according to Galatea, she wouldn't come out and it's been hours."

"Levana," Queen Alicent knocked on the door, "what's happened, child?"

"It's embarrassing, Queen Alicent," Levana responded. The Queen could make out that the princess had been crying because of the way she sounded.

"Will you let me in, Levana?" Queen Alicent requested as the door opened, Levana peeked outside the door. The Queen let out a sigh of relief as the princess seemed to be okay, however, there was an unmistakable scent that quickly filled the Queen's nose.

Queen Alicent looked at the princess to see a bloodied gown.

"Galatea," Queen Alicent called, "please give the princess another bath and prepare a fresh set of her inner clothes."

Galatea nodded and made her way into the bath. Queen Alicent then turned to Ser Westerling who bowed his head slightly, "please call for the maesters," the Queen stated as the knight nodded and made his way out of the room.

"Levana, I will talk to you before we head to the feast." The Queen stated as she took a seat on the princess' bed, eyeing the dress that she chose. She was still trying to decipher where she first saw it but she still couldn't put a finger on it.

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Moments later, the princess was already dressed and Galatea had just finished fixing her hair. The princess remained silent throughout the whole ordeal - especially so when Galatea left the room.

"Levana, I want you to know that what happened to you is normal," Queen Alicent stated as she took the princess' hand in hers, "bleeding only means that you've become a lady."

"What will people think of me?" Levana asked, "is this typical for a princess?"

Queen Alicent smiled in amusement, "it's normal for all females," she stated, "all women bleed when they have become women."

"Am I still pure?"

The question made Queen Alicent worried before embracing her, "yes, you are but at this point, you must be more careful."

Levana wrapped her arms around the Queen and sobbed into her chest, "it's okay, Levana, you are okay," the older female assured.

"The people are waiting for you," Queen Alicent stated as she broke the embrace and held the princess' hand tightly.

Although she was unsure of herself, Queen Alicent escorted the princess to the dining hall. Handing her hand over to Aemond who looked at Levana with a worried expression.

"She's well, Aemond," Queen Alicent whispered, "but you will have to keep a close eye on her from now on," she stated as she walked ahead of the two, nodding to the squire who cleared his throat.

Princess Levana of Houses Targaryen and Velaryon, the second-in-line to inherit the Iron Throne, and Prince Aemond Targaryen, the future King Consort.

ã€ğŸğŸ“ã€‘

[Italics denote Valyrian speech.]

Â 

Levana walked alongside Aemond, her heart pounding against her chest as she saw her entire family waiting for her at the end of the table. Time seemed to be slower and so was Aemond - so much so that Levana wanted to run towards the table to end the entire ordeal but her betrothed held her hand tightly and smiled at her.

"Relax," Aemond whispered, "I'm here."

The princess's expression softened as she nodded at him. They finished the march towards the table and after bowing to their family, Aemond and Levana were allowed to take their seats at the table. Levana sat at the right of the king along with her parents while the prince sat with his family at the king's left.

"Are you alright, love?" Rhaenyra asked as Levana nodded.

"Do you need a maester, Ana?" Jacaerys whispered from beside their mother as the princess shook her head.

"I'm fine, I promise."

With that, the crowd's attention turned to King Viserys who cleared his throat and glanced at his family as well as the people who gathered at the dining hall.

"Be welcome as we join together in celebration," King Viserys began, "the festivities of the last few days have led us to this grand feast to honor my first grandchild, Princess Levana."

The crowd clapped as the king gestured towards Levana who stood up and bowed at the crowd before smiling.

"It was become a Targaryen family tradition, from Levana's birth, to gaze upon the Harvest Moon that is at its highest during her Name Day," The king continued, "tonight, we share this tradition with everyone as I invite you all to come to the Godswood after the feast to watch as the moon reaches its peak."

The crowd cheered as Levana took a seat. The king gestured for the crowd to settle before looking at his cousin, Princess Rhaenys with a sad expression, "by request of Princess Levana, we also honor the late Ser Laenor Velaryon, my granddaughter's father."

Levana looked down at her lap and pursed her lips. This would be her first Name Day without her father and she longed to have his presence with her.

"Tonight, we also formally announce the betrothal of Princess Levana Velaryon to my son, Prince Aemond Targaryen as we once again unite the two houses to herald in a new age of dragons."

The crowd cheered its loudest as Levana smiled and looked over to Aemond who glanced at her before quickly turning his head toward the crowd. The king would then take a seat before walking gesturing towards Princess Rhaenyra who stood up from her chair and looked towards the crowd.

"I admit," Princess Rhaenyra began, "this is nostalgic as I have also been in my daughter's place in such a grand celebration such as this."

The crowd settled down slightly as the princess looked at her daughter, "please allow me to read a letter from my late husband addressed to our daughter for this day."

Princess Rhaenyra picked up an envelope from the table and opened it to reveal a letter that she unraveled.

Â 

To my beloved daughter,

I look at you every day and I grow prouder of you as every second passes by. I watch you grow and I couldn't be happier that the gods have given me a daughter who was born with a heart and mind such as yours.

You are the best sister to your brothers and the best daughter born to us. I know that your mother is just as proud of you as I am - maybe even prouder. I believe that you will grow into the woman that will unite the seven realms and rule just as your Grandsire and your mother after him.

Carry with you the wisdom of your grandsires and the love of your grandmothers. You are born of the blood of Old Valyria, carry this proudly.

I am always with you.

With all my love,

Your father, Laenor Velaryon

Â 

Levana couldn't stop herself from tearing up. Jacaerys and Lucerys got up from their seats to embrace their older sister. Rhaenys and Corlys looked at each other before glancing at their grandchildren.

"Your father wrote this for you during your last Name Day," Rhaenyra explained, "it was his wish to give this to you the next time the Harvest Moon took to the skies," she continued before handing the letter to Levana who sobbed as she accepted it.

This was her father's last gift to her.

"We would also like to bestow a gift to Princess Levana," Otto stated as he stood up from his chair.

"On behalf of my family, House Hightower, I present to the Princess this necklace," Otto continued as he opened a box to present to the crowd, "made of Valyrian steel, rubies, and emeralds to honor your Name Day."

The Hand of the King walked towards the princess and placed the box in front of her before retreating back to his seat. Levana gave him a small nod of acknowledgment as she held her brothers' hands in hers.

The Queen would stand soon after, "Princess Levana, in the few months that she has lived with us, has become like a child to me and the king," she stated, "as such, we would like to bestow a special gift to the princess and to her betrothed."

King Viserys nodded before standing as well, he picked up a box from in front of him and opened it to reveal two rings.

"These rings belonged to myself and my late wife, Queen Aemma," King Viserys began, "I think of no other pair fitting to wear them than the two of you."

"These will be the rings that you'll wear on your wedding day," Queen Alicent stated, "and the rings that will unite the two of you in matrimony."

Alicent placed a hand on Aemond's shoulder as Rhaenyra placed a kiss on the top of Levana's head.

"Let the feast begin!" King Viserys announced happily before returning to his seat. The Queen and the Princess would also take their seats. Lucerys and Jacaerys stayed by their sister's side, embracing her tightly as the princess glanced through the letter over and over.

The crowd had begun to gather on the dance floor as the music played. Lord Corlys stood up from his seat and walked towards Levana, offering his hand to her.

"Might I have a dance with you, granddaughter?" Lord Corlys asked as Levana tucked her father's letter in a pocket hidden within the skirt of her dress before getting up from her seat and nodding. She took her Grandsire's hand in hers. Lord Corlys would then lead her to the dance floor where the crowd made space for them.

"I hope you don't mind, little ocean," Lord Corlys began, "but your grandmother and I already gave our present to you in advance."

Levana looked at her dress and shook her head, "thank you for the dress, Grandsire, it's very beautiful."

Lord Corlys smiled, "that dress was made from the fabric of the clothes that your father wore when he married your mother."

The princess held back tears.

"Your father loved you very much, Levana," Lord Corlys whispered as the princess wrapped her arms around his waist. The sea snake placed a hand on top of her head, stroking her hair as the princess cried.

"May I cut in?"

Levana looked up to see herÂ stepfather, Daemon Targaryen, standing behind her grandfather. Lord Corlys looked at the princess and then at Daemon with a glare before stepping aside, "of course, you are Levana'sÂ stepfatherÂ after all."

Lord Corlys placed another kiss on top of Levana's head before nodding at Daemon who took the princess's hand in his. The younger girl kept her head down as she followed his movements.

"You need not be shy around me, stepdaughter," Daemon stated, "I also have a duty to protect you."

Levana looked up at him and nodded.

"I believe that I have not introduced myself formally to you,"Â Daemon began,Â "I am Prince Daemon Targaryen, your Grandsire's younger brother."

Levana's eyes lit up, it's been a while since someone spoke to her in High Valyrian.

"My name is Levana,"Â Levana smiled as Daemon nodded.

"You speak Valyrian very well,"Â Daemon commended,Â "when did you start learning?"

"I started learning when I was six,"Â Levana explained,Â "father always told mother that it was too early for me to learn it at that age but I think it was very much worth it."

Daemon smiled slightly,Â "your mother is very proud of you, I want you to know that."

Levana nodded as the music ended and the crowd clapped before the band started a new piece.

"What do I call you?"Â Levana asked,Â "you are married to my mother."

Daemon chuckled,Â "you are not asked to call me anything."

"But you are my stepfather."

"You may call me that, if you wish,"Â Daemon stated,Â "but you can also call me by name."

"You will not think it rude?"Â Levana asked as Daemon nodded,Â "I will not and you have my permission,"Â he responded as the princess smiled at him.

From her seat, Princess Rhaenys watched Daemon dancing with Levana. The sight left a bad taste in her mouth.

That should've been Laenor dancing with her â€” not someone else.

"Princess Rhaenys," Queen Alicent called from her seat, "if you do not find it disrespectful, might I ask where you acquired Levana's dress?"

Princess Rhaenys raised a brow, "why would you be interested to know, Your Grace?"

Queen Alicent smiled, "it looks familiar but I cannot remember where I saw it first."

The older princess chuckled before glancing at Rhaenyra and then looking towards Levana, "it was made from the garment that Laenor wore during his wedding."

Rhaenyra, upon hearing what Rhaenys said, immediately looked down at her lap â€” pretending that she didn't hear as she turned towards her sons, fussing over them.

Rhaenys saw this and smiled to herself slightly as Queen Alicent nodded a response. She didn't know how to feel about it but at the very least, she was happy that Levana got the chance to wear something from her father.

"Aemond," Queen Alicent turned to his son, "why don't you dance with Levana?"

The prince looked up at his mother and shook his head. The queen then furrowed her brows, "why not?"

"She's dancing with her father."

"You can take her from him."

Aemond turned to his mother before pushing himself away from the table and getting up to walk to the dance floor. He approached Daemon and Levana with a small glare.

"May I dance with her?" Aemond spoke up as Daemon looked at him and chuckled, "and if I say no?"

Levana's eyes widened at her stepfather's response, "I will dance with you, Aemond."

Daemon grinned as he stepped aside to allow Levana to join Aemond. Before returning to the table he looked at the two of them and leaned down to whisper to his stepdaughter.

Â 

"Be careful who you trust."

ã€ğŸğŸ”ã€‘

The entire night was filled with laughter and joy but Levana wasÂ botheredÂ by what her stepfather had told her. In fact, she couldn't look toward him at all after that encounter.

Just who was sheÂ notÂ supposed to trust?

The question continued to bother her until it was time for everyone to head to the Godswood to watch the Harvest Moon. Levana, of course, was walking ahead of everyone with Jacaerys and Lucerys by her side. The two were talking nonstop about how the moon was bright and beautiful.

When they arrived at the Godswood, the moon was already at its peak. The large moon illuminated the sky and the princess couldn't help but marvel at its beauty.

Levana found herself getting entranced by the moon as it glowed brightly. It was as if the Harvest Moon was telling her a story - enticing her to listen.

In her trance, Levana once again found herself in the same castle that she had seen a few moons ago.

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

The castle, though still unfamiliar to the princess, was bustling with people. They were all faces she didn't recognize until she again found herself in a hall where the Painted Table was erected.

Compared to her previous vision, this table glowed brighter. Levana could also see the presence of golden banners in the room. It was a sight to see but she still wished she knew what her vision was telling her.

There was a mighty roar that interrupted her train of thought â€” one that she recognized to be Vermithor's. Quickly, she rushed towards the hall to gaze upon her dragon soaring through the sky with two others.

"Make way for the Queen!"

Levana turned her end to the end of the hall where the female that she saw in her first vision stood. She was dressed in red and gold riding gear as she walked through the hall with what Levana could only distinguish as a Queensguard in tow.

Just as the figure was about to pass her, she stopped and looked down at the princess.

" The moon of your grandmother's vision will rise, Levana."

Levana was taken aback as everything turnedÂ dark.

What vision? What did her grandmother see?

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Levana realized that she was out of her trance when she was met with gentle slaps to the face by Princess Rhaenys. She was laying on the ground, her torso propped up by Rhaenyra who was ordering for the maesters. Lord Corlys was summoning guards that could help take Levana back to her chambers.

"Levana!" Rhaenyra called, "come back to us, beloved."

Levana blinked her eyes twice to see that she was being fussed over by what seemed to be herÂ entire family. Jacaerys and Lucerys were looking from a distance, the latter was crying as Rhaena and Baela tried to console them.

King Viserys and Otto were repeatedly calling for the maesters while the Queen was in the process of rallying Levana's handmaidens to help her find lighter clothing. Rhaenys and Rhaenyra remained by her side as she started to come to.

Aemond was also there but he was silent; looking over Rhaenyra's shoulder as he watched the scene unfold. Daemon was talking to one of the maesters that came early â€” by what Levana could make out from their conversation, her stepfather was asking about what could have happened to her.

"Levana, are you alright, darling?" Princess Rhaenys asked as Levana nodded and sat up. The older princess immediately wrapped her arms around her tightly, "I thought we lost you," she whispered as Levana wrapped her arms around her grandmother.

"Little moon, are you alright?" King Viserys asked, "what happened to you?"

Levana wasn't so sure if she could tell her family what her vision was but fortunately, her mother had cut in when the maester asked what happened.

"She was just looking at the moon," Rhaenyra stated, "her eyes turned white and she fell to the ground."

"How long was she unresponsive?" The maester asked as Rhaenys looked up at him, "a couple of minutes but she has never done this before."

"Princess Rhaenys is right," Queen Alicent seconded, "Levana has never shown this type of behavior in the months that she's been with us and she watches the moon with Aemond most evenings."

"Has she done this before, Princess Rhaenyra?" The maester asked as Rhaenyra thought for a while.

"I've seen her in a trance before," Rhaenyra stated, "but she did not faint like this nor did her eyes turn white."

"When did this happen?" Queen Alicent asked.

"The day that she claimed Vermithor," Rhaenyra responded, "she was flying on her dragon and she seemed to be in a trance for a few moments but she easily recovered back then."

"Princess Levana," One of the maesters called, "how do you feel?"

Levana shrugged, "I feel fine," she responded, "I don't feel anything."

"Are you sure?" The maester asked as Lord Corlys knelt beside the princess, "Levana, tell us the truth."

Levana nodded, "I don't feel anything, honest."

"I think it best if the princess is allowed to retire and rest for the remainder of the evening," Queen Alicent stated as King Viserys nodded in agreement.

"Allow me to escort the princess to her chambers," Rhaenyra stated as the King and Queen nodded. The two were led away by Galatea as the rest of their family remained in Godswood.

"You are all invited to return to the hall for the remainder of the feast," King Viserys stated, "please, there is still more food to eat and more wine to drink."

The guests cheered as they emptied the Godswood to return to the Grand Hall. On the other hand, Rhaenyra had just settled with Levana in the latter's chambers as Galatea helped the princess to get dressed in her nightgown.

"What happened, Ana?" Princess Rhaenyra asked as Levana looked at her mother before puffing her cheeks and thanking her handmaiden.

"Would you be needing anything else, Princess Levana?" Galatea asked as the princess shook her head.

"Enjoy the night, Galatea."

The handmaiden nodded and excused herself, closing the door behind her as Rhaenyra turned to her daughter, "I will not ask twice, Ana."

Levana huffed, "do you get visions mother?"

"What visions?" Rhaenyra asked.

"I've had two in the past months," Levana began, "one during my first flight with Vermithor and the other was earlier tonight."

"What did you see?" Rhaenyra asked, "have you told anyone else about this?"

Levana shook her head, "I'm afraid that they might think me sick if I told anyone about it."

"What did your visions show you, Ana?"

The younger princess took a deep breath, "I suspect both my visions to be in the same stronghold, they had the same Painted Table but I could never distinguish which castle it was that I was in," she stated as her mother listened intently, "each time, I would see someone wearing a golden crown with rubies in it."

Rhaenyra raised a brow, "Ana, this isn't one of your made-up stories, is it?"

Levana shook her head adamantly, "it's true, mother!"

"Go on," Rhaenyra sighed.

"I would hear people talking in the visions but I could never understand them or hear what they had to say," Levana sighed, "but I always remember that figure being referred to as the Queen."

"What else did you see?"

"I saw Vermithor with two other dragons," Levana continued, "one was a pale gray and the other was as black as night."

"Were there other dragons?" Rhaenyra asked as Levana shook her head.

"I only saw Vermithor and those two others," Levana responded, "but in my vision, I could hear more growling and roaring."

Rhaenyra marveled at her daughter's vision - thinking it to be a sign of the future that would come with their reign.

"You must rest," Rhaenyra stated, "you've had a long night."

Levana nodded as she walked towards her bed as the older princess motioned toward the door, opening it slightly when Levana spoke, "will you be here when I wake up tomorrow, mother?"

Rhaenyra smiled before walking towards her and placing a kiss on her forehead, "I will be here when you wake up and then again when you sleep tomorrow evening."

Levana smiled at her mother's gesture before tucking herself into bed.

"See you in the morning, mother."

Rhaenyra nodded, "I will see you in the morn, my love."Â 

ã€ğŸğŸ•ã€‘

[Italics denote Valyrian speech]

Â 

The memory of her tenth Name Day would be one that became a distant memory as many moons passed through the sky.

Though, the memory of her visions would remain to be a continued sight in the princess' dreams. The visions would come and go - they'd become more frequent as the princess became older but she would have little to no memory of the other visions that she saw as she matured no matter how vivid they would be.

Still, what would not leave her is the memory of the figure wearing a gold crown adorned with rubies and the sight of her dragon flying with two others.

Levana supposed that it would be better for her to forget them. After all, it was only the King who heard her stories about her visions as she grew - her mother dismissed them when she reached the age of ten and four. Urging her that it would be best if her moonlit visions are forgotten and done with.

The princess was now ten and seven, practicing embroidery alongside her aunt, Helaena. The two have become closer as the years went by. Levana saw her as someone that she could confide in with no question.

"Your embroidery is beautiful, Levana," Helaena commented, "you've embroidered the Godswood exquisitely."

Levana turned to her and smiled, "thank you, Helaena," she said as she looked at her piece, "your embroidery is just as exquisite."

"I'm sure that your future children with Aemond would be glad to have you as a mother," Helaena smiled, "you would be able to embroider such beautiful cloths."

Levana smiled at the thought though it pained her.

As they grew, Aemond and her would grow distant from each other. Maybe it was due to their varying interests as the prince now also allotted time to the sword while Levana spent her time with the Queen and Helaena.

While they did find common ground in reading and dragon riding, it was simply not the same as they would only exchange a few words with each other. Levana thought it to be normal as they had to keep their distance as with custom but this was surely too much as they were such good friends prior to this.

"Speaking of Aemond," The Queen cut in, "I wonder where he is about."

Levana sighed, "I believe he was in the library earlier today as he was with Septon Salvi."

Queen Alicent noticed the discomfort in Levana's tone and placed a hand on her shoulder, "he will come around, Levana."

Levana turned to the Queen and smiled, "Your Grace, I do not wish to bother Aemond with this yet as we both have priorities and duties about us that we need to care for."

"But you are his betrothed," Queen Alicent stated, "it is also his duty to make sure that you are safe, well, and protected."

"I require no protection from the prince, Your Grace."

"Levana, my sweet daughter," The Queen sighed, "I refuse to have this argument with you again."

This, as a matter of fact, was not the first that they had argued about the duties of Aemond to Levana. The princess was content with the distance between them as she is quite capable of holding her own but Queen Alicent believes that Aemond should be available at all times to aid the princess.

Just as Levana was about to reply, the doors to the Queen's chamber opened to reveal Aemond. The prince bowed his head slightly at the ladies in front of him and turned his attention to the princess.

"Mother," Aemond said, "I ask to have a moment with Princess Levana."

The Queen chuckled, "it is not I that you should be asking permission from."

"Princess," Aemond held his hand out, "I would like to request for your company in the Godswood."

"Pray tell what are we to discuss there that we cannot discuss in the presence of Queen Mother and Helaena?" Levana smiled as the prince chuckled a response, "'tis a matter that I wish to discuss with my betrothed."

Queen Alicent looked at his son and then at Levana before smiling, "very well then, Levana, you may go."

The princess nodded and stood up from her seat, leaving her embroidery on the table before taking Aemond's hand and walking out of the room. Ser Westerling followed closely behind them as he is accustomed to

"I do wish that your sworn protector would leave distance between himself and us," Aemond whispered, "this is a delicate matter that I wish to discuss with you."

Levana nodded and turned to face the knight who had a brow raised, "if you are to tell me to leave, Princess Levana, I will refuse as ordered by King Viserys."

"I simply wish for a safe distance, Ser Westerling," Levana responded, "Aemond and I are to discuss a delicate and personal matter."

Ser Westerling sighed before nodding his head, "a safe distance is what you will receive, Your Grace."

With that, the two royals would proceed to the Godswood while Ser Westerling stayed by the castle door, watching as the two walked farther from him and nearer to the Weirwood tree.

"What do you wish to discuss, Aemond?"

"A matter of our betrothal," Aemond began, "I wish to have it broken."

Levana was taken aback, "does the Queen and King know about this?"

"They do not need to know unless we have decided," Aemond stated, "you do not wish to live a loveless marriage, do you?"

The princess raised a brow, "Aemond, what do you know about love and what I feel toward you?"

"I know that you do not love me," Aemond stated, "and whatever feelings I may have for you will wither away with the end of our betrothal."

"I refuse."

"Do not make this hard, Eva."

"How dare you assume my feelings for you and ask for this?" Levana asked, "we've prepared our entire lives for us to be wed, Aemond."

"You're not supposed to prepare for marriage for that long, I know that now," Aemond responded as Levana held back tears, "I refused to set foot on Dragonstone again to be with you."

"Levana, we were children."

"You would rather see me marry a different lord?" Levana asked, "a lord that I do not know?"

Aemond shook his head, "I am protecting you this way, Levana."

"From what, Aemond?!" Levana raised her voice enough to alert Ser Westerling who proceeded to walk towards them.

"Princess," Ser Westerling, "perhaps you should retreat to your chambers."

Levana raised a hand,Â "what are you protecting me from, Aemond?"

"It is better if you do not know, Levana,"Â Aemond stated,Â "you will be kept safer that way."

"What is it that I should not know about you, Aemond?"Â Levana asked,Â "we are friends, are we not? You can share this burdenÂ withÂ me."

"No,"Â Aemond replied bluntly,Â "Levana, this is the only way to protect my honor and yours."

"The King and the Queen will know about this,"Â Levana warned before running back into the palace. Ser Westerling turned to bow at the prince before following after the princess.

ã€ğŸğŸ–ã€‘

Rumors were meant to be kept as whispers in the halls. But no matter how silent the whispers were, Levana still heard them and they haunted her so.

They began as hushed whispers in the courtyard before moving up to be echoes in the Red Keep's hallowed halls. Levana wished that she could be away from them and forget but it wasn't that easy â€” especially when her future with Aemond was on the line.

Still, the rumor had her at wit's end which prompted her to sneak out of the palace in the dead of night. She found herself in the streets of King's Landing in search of someone who many know as theÂ White Worm.

Meanwhile, Aemond was in the company of his parents and Grandsire in the safety of the council chamber. The prince made his intentions clear to those present and his elders looked at him disappointedly.

"If the rumors are true," Otto began, "the earlier your wedding must happen."

"I will not marry Levana," Aemond stated, "her honor is worth more than this engagement."

"You dishonor her by even thinking about ending your engagement!" Queen Alicent interjected as her son shook his head.

The Queen sighed, "she has not been sleeping nor eating properly."

"Does she know?" Aemond asked, "has someone told her about the rumors?"

King Viserys turned to his youngest son and nodded, "nobody has to tell Levana," he stated, "she has her ways of finding out on her own."

"Then you will accept my request, father?" Aemond asked as King Viserys chuckled a response.

"You mean to break an engagement over a baseless rumor?" King Viserys laughed, "you will have to fight me to the death before I allow it."

For a while, Aemond considered his father's challenge. He was a capable fighter but he also imagined that he wouldn't take it to such extremes.

"Aemond," Queen Alicent began, "Levana loves you and gods forbid that you deny that you feel the same about her."

"Motherâ€”"

"We are not blind, Aemond," Queen Alicent added, "you do not look at anyone the way that you look at Levana and the way that you act around her is vastly different."

"And if the rumors are true?" Aemond asked, "what of it then?"

"The Crown denies all rumors that relate to you and Daemon Targaryen," Otto stated, "such a rumor is an act of treason to House Targaryen, and whoever spread it will be found and punished."

"Meanwhile, you will reconcile with Levana," Queen Alicent stated, "and you will take back what you said about breaking your betrothal."

"She deserves more than everything that I have to give," Aemond began, "she will be the Queen."

King Viserys looked at his son and sighed, "Aemond, you are a prince of the House of the Dragon," he began, "no other prince or lord in the Seven Realms can compare to what you have and what you will give to your betrothed."

With that, Aemond nodded and excused himself from the table - he would need to find Levana and make his amends before the princess truly decided to break their engagement because of his actions.

"Galatea," Aemond called as he approached Levana's chambers, "is Eva inside?"

Galatea bowed to the prince and nodded, "she hasn't been coming out for the past few days and even Princess Helaena is worried for her."

For the first time in his life, Aemond felt absolutelyÂ stupid.

"Eva," Aemond knocked but was met with no response.

Worried that something might have happened to her, Aemond, quite literally, kicked the door open to reveal an empty chamber.

"Eva!"

Aemond must've looked through all of the corners in Levana's chambers but she was still not in sight.

"Where is Ser Westerling?" Aemond asked, turning to Galatea who looked just as worried as the prince.

"Ser Harold was asked to tend to the King today, my Prince," Galatea responded, "I was preparing the princess' meal."

Aemond looked through the papers on Levana's desk, stopping at the sight of a name that he had heard the servants talking about.

White Worm.

He grabbed the piece of paper as he walked out of the room, "get me Ser Criston and alert the City Watch that the princess is in King's Landing."

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

In the years that she's lived in the Red Keep, she has never been outside its walls to see what has become of King's Landing.

It was unsightly, to say the least.

The princess found herself wandering through the alleys - not that she knew where she was supposed to go. All she had was a name to go by and she knew better than to ask around as someone might even recognize her if she said anything.

"Hey, lady," a voice called.

Levana turned around to see a small child looking up at her.

"She knows that you're looking for her," the child stated as he stretched his hand out, "I'll take you to her."

"To whom, exactly?"

"To my mistress."

"Mistress?" Levana asked, "who?"

"The one that you're looking for," the child responded.

Before she knew it, she had accepted the child's hand and they were making their way through the back alleys of King's Landing before retreating to a staircase in a building that Levana didn't even recognize where.

"It's been a while since I've had Targaryen royalty under my roof."

"Are you the White Worm?" Levana asked as the figure in front of her turned around to face her.

"You look so much like your stepfather," the White Worm stated, "are you sure you're not his?"

"I have Velaryon blood," Levana stated, "and it runs true."

The White Worm smiled at her and gestured for her to take a seat on one of the chairs in the room. The princess would then take a seat, trying to formulate her sentences as the other female sat in front of her.

"Most people come to me if they wish to know something," the other female stated, "do you come for the same purpose?"

Levana nodded, "I need to know who began the rumors about Prince Aemond."

"Does the prince know that you have come to me to defend his honor?"

The princess shook his head, "he does not need to know," she stated, "I am doing this for him."

The White Worm looked at her with an amused expression, "are you in love with the prince?"

"I don't know," Levana responded, "I can't tell."

"The fact that you are here says a lot," The older female stated, "no one in their right mind would escape from the castle in broad daylight if they did not care for the person that they are speaking for."

"Will you help me?" Levana asked, "even if Aemond does decide to break our betrothal, I would at least want to put his mind at ease."

"Very well, princess," the White Worm smiled, "but it comes with a price."

Levana nodded and produced a small bag of gold from the pocket of her cloak, "will this suffice?"

"I am not robbing you, princess," the female chuckled, "because you have been such a nice guest, you can name your price."

"But I'm asking you for a service," Levana stated, "shouldn't you be naming the price for it?"

"Cunning and respectful," the White Worm smiled, "the mark of a princess."

Levana smiled at her as she held out the bag for the woman to take. The White Worm nodded and took the bag in her hands, opening it and taking a couple of pieces from the bag.

"You may call me Mysaria, my princess."

"Is that your name?"

Mysaria nodded as she returned the bag to the princess and stood up to take a piece of paper from her desk. She would then scribble something down before handing it to the princess.

"You will find the name of your traitor there," Mysaria stated as Levana took the piece of paper and hit it in the secret pocket of her dress skirt.

"The child outside will escort you back to the palace," Mysaria smiled.

The princess nodded and bowed her head.

"If you need me again, princess, you know where to find me now."

Levana nodded and left the place, looking around for the little boy who escorted her through the streets but he was nowhere to be found. Instead, the princess decided for herself to try and locate her way back to the palace.

Â 

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Aemond insisted on accompanying Ser Westerling to look for his betrothed in King's Landing and despite protests from the Queen, the prince would still have his way.

"Why do you think the princess would look for the White Worm, my prince?" Ser Criston asked as Aemond held up the piece of paper she found in Levana's room, "she was trying to find whoever began those rumors about my parentage."

"Forgive me, My Prince, but how sure are you of this?" Ser Criston asked as Aemond stopped in his tracks.

"I know Eva too well," Aemond responded, "we've spent too much time together for me not to know what she is like."

Ser Westerling listened to the exchange with an amused smile, "they were inseparable when they were growing up."

Ser Criston was about to respond when a commotion in the square caught their attention. Immediately, the knights of the City Watch rushed toward the scene, Aemond following after them.

The brawl was getting larger by the second and the City Watch had to summon more of their men to break it apart. Aemond looked around to try and find Levana and as it turns out, he didn't need to look too far.

"Aemond!"

Aemond rushed toward the center of the brawl, finding Levana easily enough.

"Damsel in distress does not suit you, Eva," Aemond chuckled as he wrapped an arm around Levana's shoulders, maneuvering their way out of the brawl.

Ser Westerling spotted and quickly summoned the City Watch to surround the prince and the princess for them to be escorted safely back to the palace. The City Watch made sure that the prince and princess were hauled into the carriage that waited for them before breaking up the brawl.

Aemond kept Levana close to him as they boarded the carriage. The two sat beside each other as the princess leaned her head against the prince's shoulder. Aemond held her tightly as the carriage made its way back to the castle.

"I hope you found what you were looking for," Aemond whispered as Levana nodded.

Levana hummed, "it was a fruitful visit to the city, that's for sure."Â 

ã€ğŸğŸ—ã€‘

Upon their return to the Red Keep, it was expected that they were to be met with a scolding - especially Levana who had taken it upon herself to â€œfind justiceâ€ for Aemond. When all that was said and done, Levana found herself in the solace of her room where she would finally find out who it was who began the rumors about Aemond in the first place.Â 

Taking a deep breath, Levana unraveled the paper. Immediately, she felt as though her heart would escape from her chest.

Daemon Targaryen.

Her own stepfather.Â 

But why?

Her thoughts were interrupted by the opening of her door to reveal Aemond and Galatea who had a tray of tea in her hands. The princess was quick to hide the piece of paper beneath the others that were on her desk before getting up and taking a seat on the couch.

â€œMay I?â€ Aemond asked as Levana nodded as her handmaiden set the tea on the table before bowing. Galatea glanced at the princess before closing the door behind her.Â 

â€œThe rumor thatâ€™s been spread about me,â€ Aemond began as he took a seat opposite the princess, â€œit was that my true father was Daemon Targaryen and not the king.â€Â 

Levana nodded. Sheâ€™s heard the rumors - a plethora of them even.Â 

â€œIf the rumors were true,â€ Aemond continued, â€œI would be a bastard and I didnâ€™t want you to live with that embarrassment especially since I had called your brothers the same thing.â€Â 

â€œAemond--â€Â 

â€œLet me finish, Eva.â€Â 

Levana nodded and poured tea for the both of them. She waited for the prince to continue his piece as she took her own cup in her hands.Â 

â€œI didnâ€™t want you to be married to a bastard.â€Â 

â€œWho says you were one?â€ Levana asked, â€œyou are the son of King Viserys Targaryen and Queen Alicent.â€Â

â€œI didnâ€™t want Daemon to takeÂ  you away from me too, Aemond.â€Â

Â 

Prince Aemond did well on his promise to earn back Princess Levana's love and trust in the year that they were preparing for marriage. While they maintained civil in the eyes of others, the two would retreat to the library to find time for themselves - still under the watchful eye of Ser Westerling but they were still glad to have time for them.

Queen Alicent and King Viserys were overjoyed that the two of them would continue their engagement and began to plan the wedding immediately. Sending invitations as early as six moons in advance for the special day.

"How about we also have a traditional Valyrian wedding?" Levana asked, looking over at her betrothed who looked up from his book beside her.

"Eva," Aemond began, "we promised to the Queen that we would do most things her way."

"Still, Aemond," Levana sighed, "I want to be married by tradition and not just religion."

"Eva."

"Aemond, we're both Targaryens," Levana stated, "and I am also of Velaryon blood, the blood of Old Valyria runs deep within us."

"They will never agree," Aemond began, "not everyone in the Seven Kingdoms is familiar with our traditions."

"Then maybe it should just be the both of us," Levana suggested, "we can have Galatea and Ser Westerling as witnesses."

"Who will officiate the wedding, Eva?" Aemond asked.

The question left the female in thought, on one hand, her betrothed was correct - there was no one familiar with the custom except her Grandsire in King's Landing. The closest that they would have are Levana's immediate family and her paternal grandparents.

"We can fly to Dragonstone," Levana suggested, "we can do it in the guise of a visit and I can ask my mother to officiate for us."

"She will never agree."

"I know she will," Levana stated firmly.

"Levana, we cannot get married in secret," Aemond said as Levana smiled.

"It's not a secret if my mother knows," Levana said sheepishly as Aemond shook his head in defeat.

"Eva, my moon," Aemond began, "can it at least wait until our wedding and duty to the realm are done?"

The princess puffed her cheeks and nodded, "if this is the compromise that I must agree with, then I accept, my love."

The prince stood up from his seat and walked towards the princess, wrapping his arms around her shoulders as he looked at what the princess was reading, "ah, Visenya Targaryen, my wife's favorite role model."

"Your wife?"Â Levana giggled,Â "do not call me that yet, Aemond, I might get used to it."

"I would prefer that you do get used to it,"Â Aemond responded, placing a chaste kiss on the top of her head,Â "you will be my wife soon, and I, your husband."

"Aemond,"Â the princess looked up at her betrothed, "hm?" Aemond responded as Levana placed a hand on top of his.

"I want children,"Â Levana stated,Â "we have not discussed this matter yet but I want to make my intentions clear."

"Children, we shall have,"Â Aemond responded,Â "and I swear to be the best father to them."

The princess looked at him with disbelief,Â "you agree with me?"

"Why wouldn't I?"Â Aemond said,Â "to have children with you, Princess Levana Velaryon, would be an honor."

"I already have a name if we were to have a girl,"Â Levana smiled.

"Let me guess," Aemond placed one of his hands on the book that Levana was reading, "I wager that you want to name our daughter, Visenya."

Levana nodded, "Visenya and if we have a boy, I would like him to be named Baelon."

"Is there an attachment to the name?"

Levana nodded before hanging her head low,Â "Baelon was the name of mother's younger brother,"Â she stated,Â "he died just a couple of hours after he was born."

"Eva..."

"The only living thing that we have to remember him by is Sunfyre,"Â Levana smiled,Â "that dragon was supposed to be his."

"I suppose your mother told you this story?" Aemond asked.

"Aemond," Levana began, "Baelon's egg was the only one that was laid before Aegon's birth and as such, the egg would go to him."

"A question of dragons and eggs," Aemond moved away from Levana to stand beside her, leaning against the table. The prince held the princess' hand and looked at her, "I do not think that Vhagar has the capability to still lay eggs, my love."

Levana thought for a while, "Aemond, the gods will provide."

"That or maybe his uncles can get him a pig to ride on," Aemond responded to which Levana responded by slapping his knee.

"That's our child, Aemond!"

"Your brothers thought of it a joke," Aemond teased, "as our child's father, I am allowed to jest," the prince chuckled as the doors of the library opened to reveal Queen Alicent with Galatea by his side.

"My Queen," Levana said as she stood up from her seat to bow to the woman who smiled at her.

"Aemond, may I borrow Princess Levana for a moment?" Queen Alicent asked, "dresses for the wedding have arrived and she needs to pick one that she will wear to the ceremony."

Aemond nodded and turned to Levana, lifting up her hand to place a kiss on her knuckles before the princess walked to the Queen's side.

"Your father wishes to see you," The Queen smiled at Aemond, "there is also a matter that he wishes to discuss with you with regard to the wedding."

The prince nodded as the females left. He would then head to his father's chambers to meet him about his concerns. Since the announcement of their wedding, both the King and Queen have allotted time to help the prince and princess with their planning - going as far as to arrange the menu and venue for them so the betrothed can focus on more personal aspects of the wedding.

The prince knocked on his father's door, "My King, it's Aemond."

"Enter," King Visersys said from inside the room as the prince opened the doors. Aemond walked inside his father's chambers, closing the door behind him before facing the King and bowing his head.

"You called for me, father?" Aemond asked as King Viserys nodded. The King gestured toward a cloak laid on one of the chairs in his room, "this will be Levana's bridal cloak."

Aemond approached the chair and lifted the cloak. The majority of the garment was red and black with golden accents that made it stand out. It was a beautiful cloak - very different to what Helaena wore during her own wedding.

"That belonged to Queen Aemma," King Viserys stated, "Levana's grandmother."

The prince turned to his father and bowed his head, "it's an honor that you would allow us to use this, My King."

King Viserys chuckled a response, "Levana is my favorite granddaughter," he stated, "I only wish the best for her and you."

"I will protect her, father," Aemond vowed.

"I expect nothing less," the King responded, "she will be the Queen, Aemond, and I trust that you will protect her."

"With all that I am and all that I ever will be."

"Aemond," King Viserys sighed, "do not take this lightly, my son, the line of my succession is still widely being debated despite my declarations for Rhaeynra and I am almost certain that a war will be fought over it."

"Father, you need not--"

"You will stick by Levana's side at all costs," King Viserys said, "even if it means abandoning the Red Keep and whoever takes my place as king, do you understand?"

Aemond straightened up and looked at the bridal cloak again before bowing his head.

"I understand, My King."

ã€ğŸ‘ğŸã€‘

[Italics denote Valyrian speech]

Â 

King Viserys vowed that his son and granddaughter would have the grandest wedding in the Seven Realms and he did well on his promise.

The celebration was to be seven days long with attendees expected to come from all over the Seven Kingdoms as well as envoys of the Free Cities and Dorne. Many believed that this wedding would rival that of the former King Jaehaerys I and Queen Alyssane with the lot calling it the "Second Golden Wedding".

Before the wedding ceremony, there would be six days of feasts, hunts, and tourneys - Lord Corlys himself volunteered to hold a mock sea battle, reminiscent of the original Golden Wedding. Meanwhile, Levana's younger brothers as well as Baela volunteered to do a dragon exhibition at the Dragonpit - they even got Aegon to join them as well, seeing as he was the one with the largest dragon among them â€” apart from the couple who they would be honoring.

Princess Rhaenyra and Levana's family arrived seven days before the start of the celebration to assist with the preparations. Rhaenyra along with Princess Rhaenys would join Queen Alicent and Levana in choosing dresses while DaemonÂ triedÂ his best to assist Aemond - much to the younger prince's distaste but he would have to live with it upon his betrothed's request.

"Ana, my love, I believe Princess Rhaenys has a gift for you," Rhaenyra stated as the aforementioned princess nodded. The four ladies were seated in the Queen's chambers where Levana was in the process of choosing her wedding dress and the other dresses that she would wear throughout the ceremony â€” a task that was far from over.

Galatea brought over a large box that she set on the table in front of the royals. She bowed her head before retreating to the door.

"This will be your maiden's cloak," Princess Rhaenys began, "this was my bridal cloak when I married your Grandsire and I think of no one else to use this but you," she continued before opening the box to reveal a cloak that was adorned with the Velaryon crest and in the colors of the house. Though, arguably, the most striking detail about the garment was the gold embellishments that scattered across it - made the garment stand out so much more.

"Thank you, grandma," Levana embraced Rhaenys tightly, "this means so much to me."

"Congratulations, Levana," Rhaenys whispered as her granddaughter broke the embrace to return to her seat beside the Queen. All the while, Levana had her eyes on the cloak, admiring it.

"There is also a question of who is to give you away, Ana," Rhaenyra said, "as your father is gone,Â weÂ have yet to decide who will give you away."

Levana shrugged, "I would like my Grandsire, Lord Corlys, to give me away."

"Ana, you have a stepfathâ€”"

"Mother," Levana sighed as Rhaenyra stopped, "with all the respect that is due, Daemon is not a Velaryon and I am not of his blood."

"Ana, I implore you to let him be a part of this."

"He is a part of it already," The younger princess began, "I'm allowing him to participate in whatever way he wants but I do not want him to give me away as he didn't raise me nor did he play a big part in my life."

"Princess Rhaenyra, I believe Levana has made her decision, she will be given away by Lord Corlys," Queen Alicent stated in finality as Levana nodded at the former before turning back to her mother.

"My grandsire raised me when Daemon did not," Levana added, "he was there for me even as a child and after my father's death where as I only met my stepfather during my tenth Name Day."

Rhaenyra looked at her daughter with disbelief before nodding in defeat, "I suppose Lord Corlys is the best person to stand in for your father."

"Lord Corlys is the only person who can represent my father," Levana stated,Â "there is no one else."

The princess' mother leaned back against her chair in defeat,Â "very well, it is your wedding."

"Mother, do not hold this against me,"Â Levana sighed as she reached out to hold her mother's hand,Â "but I believe that the best person to stand in the absence of my father is his own."

Rhaenys listened in on their conversation and smiled slightly. Even with the years that she spent in the Red Keep, Levana has not forgotten her love for her paternal grandparents and their love for her.

"Princess," Queen Alicent called, "there is a matter of your wedding dress, you still have not chosen and we are drawing nearer to the date of the ceremony."

"God forbid that you're still choosing on the days of the hunt, the tourney, and the sea battle," Rhaenys chuckled, "Lord Corlys would want you to witness the might of the Velaryon fleet."

"Your Graces," Galatea called from the door, "the new batch of dresses from the seamstresses are here."

"My daughter," the Queen turned to Levana, "this is the fifth batch and we are running out of time as all your other dresses have been chosen."

Levana nodded, she would have to make a decision sooner or later.

"May Aemond come and choose with me?" Levana asked as all three elders looked at each other before Rhaenyra shook her head, "beloved, it's considered to be bad luck if my brother would see you in the dresses before the day of the ceremony."

"He need not see me wear them," Levana reasoned, "he can come in and choose from the spread."

"It amazes me how Levana wants Aemond to be very involved with everything," Rhaenys smiled, "they must have a strong bond."

"When we arrived, he came to me," Rhaenyra said, "he came to ask for my permission to marry Levana."

"He asked permission from Lord Corlys and I as well," Rhaenys chuckled, "I am relieved to know that the boy is genuine with his intentions towards Levana."

"It is decided," Queen Alicent sighed, "Aemond will assist the princess in choosing her bridal gown so that Levana might be able to finally make a decision."

Levana smiled at the Queen who did the same. Rhaenyra watched the exchange and couldn't help but feel as though she had been cheated of her relationship with Levana. Although there was also a part of her that knew she had a fault for not being able to have a relationship with her firstborn daughter.

Rhaenyra made that decision on her own and there was no one else to blame but herself.

"Galatea, please summon for Aemond," Levana turned to her handmaiden, "please tell him that I request his presence."

Galatea nodded and quickly left the Queen's chambers to inform Aemond of Levana's request. Meanwhile, the princess would continue to inspect the dresses laid out for her. For the princess, choosing a dress was a much more difficult task than learning how to properly maneuver her dragon across King's Landing.

"Levana, while we're here and in the discussion of the wedding," Queen Alicent took a seat on one of the couches, "have you and Aemond decided on the venue for the ceremony?"

"Yes, we have, Queen Mother and you'll be excited to hear that we've---"

"We've decided to hold it in the Dragonpit."

Levana turned towards the door where Aemond stood. The prince bowed to the females in front of him as his bride approached him, wrapping an arm around his own as she led him into the room.

"The Dragonpit?" Rhaenyra raised a brow, "a bold choice."

"We will have the ceremony at the Dragonpit then the wedding party shall proceed to the Red Keep," Levana explained, "and at the dawn of the day after, we'll have a Valyrian wedding ceremony."

"What Valyrian Ceremony?" Queen Alicent asked, "I was not informed of this."

"Levana and I were to discuss it with you, mother," Aemond stated," but we would like to be wed the way our ancestors were."

"I see no problem with that," Princess Rhaenys stated, "they are both from the blood of Old Valyria."

"There is no one that would preside over the ceremony," Queen Alicent stated, "as much as I would like to grant this request, no one will preside for you."

Levana and Aemond looked at each other with a smile before turning to Princess Rhaenys. The Queen Who Never Was looked at them with a raised brow before turning her attention to Levana who had a sheepish smile.

"I know what you're about to say," Rhaenys sighed, "perhaps not I but one of your grandsires might."

"I will ask them at once," Levana smiled as she motioned to leave with Aemond but they were stopped by the Queen.

"You can ask them later," Queen Alicent stated as she gestured towards the dresses, "you asked for Aemond to be brought here to help you choose a gown."

"Did you?" Aemond looked at Levana who nodded in response. The prince shook his head in amusement before turning around to inspect the dresses.

Meanwhile, Rhaenyra observed them, a smile on her face as she watched her daughter. Levana looked to be content with Aemond's company and as her mother, that was all she could ask for - for the young princess to have a husband that would love her with no repercussions.

'I only wish you could see this, Laenor,'Â Rhaenyra thought as she continued to watch Levana and her betrothed with a smile on her face.Â

The festivities that led to the grand wedding ceremony were attended by all their guests - from the tourney to the dragon exhibition and to the mock sea battle - Levana and Aemond made sure that they would be there to not only participate in it but also be able to greet their guests personally.Â 

The ladies in attendance took a liking to the princess for her beauty and wit while the lords admired Aemondâ€™s perceptiveness and honor. Both of them nearly found no time to spend with each other as the festivities went about - though, they did enjoy flying together when they were asked by Jacaerys to participate in the dragon exhibition.Â 

This was the day of the grand wedding ceremony and the whole of the Red Keep was busy preparing for it. Levana sat in her chambers with her brothers and stepsisters as they waited for the carriage that would deliver her and Aemond to Kingsroad where they would mount their dragons and make a grand entrance at the Dragonpit.Â 

Rhaena and Baela were fussing over Levanaâ€™s hair as Jacaerys and Lucerys admired their older sister. From her seat, Levana looked into the mirror in front of her and admired the dress that Aemond chose for the ceremony.Â 

As with tradition, the dress was white. It was a long-sleeved dress with a bodice designed in a way to resemble armor. The dress was topped with a gem-covered greatcloak that Levana imagined would look divine when she would take to the skies. The accents and embellishments were all gold - the shade had become a signature color of the princess. Completing the dress was a necklace that bore the Velaryon crest and on her head was a circlet adorned with a mixture of rubies, emeralds, and citrine.Â 

Levana also wore jewelry that the Queen and her mother gave her for the occasion. Her mother gave her a pair of earrings while Queen Alicent gave the princess one of her rings. King Viserys would also extend the same courtesy to Aemond, bestowing upon him one of his own rings as well.

â€œStop staring at me,â€ Levana chuckled as she looked at Lucerys, â€œitâ€™s making me more nervous than I already am.â€Â

â€œJace?â€ Levana called, â€œis there something wrong?"Â
