The two exchanged words of love to each other as the prince assured his wife that they would make sure their children won't be accessories to the war. They went as far as discussing where they would send them on the off chance that they would need to get involved.

Their children were their first priority - that was without question.

As they arrived at the Dragonpit, the two waited for their carriage doors to open and they would be escorted to where the coronation was to happen. Aemond fastened his sword to his waist while Levana reached down to pat at her thigh in the guise of fixing her dress but in reality, she was checking if the dagger that her Grandsire left for her was safely in place.

It didn't take long for Ser Nandor to open the door of their carriage to escort them. The prince held Levana's hand tightly in his as they navigated through the Dragonpit. It was arranged in a way that was similar to what they had at their wedding - only today's event was much grimmer for Levana.

By standing with her husband, her own mother would consider her to be a traitor.

Helaena stood just beside her, fiddling with her fingers as Otto stepped up to address the crowd:

Â 

People of King's Landing, today is the saddest of days.

Our beloved king, Viserys the Peaceful, has died. But it is also the most joyous of days for as his spirit left us, he whispered his final wish that Aegon II, his firstborn son, should succeed him.

Â 

Levana watched as the crowd clapped in joy - they would have a King to succeed her Grandsire. Her other hand balled into a fist as the crowd's cheers began to get louder.

"Today, we also crown a new Queen," Otto added as the now Dowager Queen walked to the center of the stage. She called for Helaena who turned her head toward Levana with a sad smile. The latter could only give her a smile of assurance as she walked toward Dowager Queen Alicent who held in her hands a crown.

"People of King's Landing," Alicent began, "I present to you, Queen Helaena Targaryen, the Queen Consort," she announced as she placed a crown on Helaena's head. Levana removed her hand from Aemond's grasp to clap - at the very least, there was Helaena that she could be happy for.

The cheers were interrupted by the marching of the guards who assembled by the crowd. They marched a line from one of the entrances and from where she was standing, Levana could see that some of them were members of the City Watch.

Trumpets began to play as the knights held their swords in reverence to Aegon who began making his way through the crowd. As Aegon passed them, they let their swords fall to their sides until he reached the stage where they held their swords to their chests.

Otto began to speak once more:

Â 

It is your great good fortune and privilege to be here to witness this.

A new day for our city, a new day for our realms, and a new king to lead us.

Â 

Aegon looked at Levana with a sad expression as Levana smirked at him. While she did feel bad for him, he accepted the role to participate in her mother's usurpation and that did not sit well with Levana. Though, what irked the princess more was the Hand's speech - addressing the people of the realm that to be in the presence of such a treacherous act was a privilege.

Gods help them.

Once Aegon was on the stage, the knights let their swords fall as the Dowager Queen placed a kiss on the prince's forehead. The High Septon then approached them as Aegon knelt down.

The High Septon took oil in his hands as he began to say:

May the Warrior give him courage. May the Smith lend strength to his sword and shield.

The Grand Septon began to anoint Aegon with oil as he continued:

May the Father defend him in his need. May the Crone lift her shining lamp and light his way to wisdom.

Levana watched as the High Septon then handed the crown to Ser Criston who now served as the Commander of the Kingsguard - replacing Ser Harold.

This was when Levana realized that this was an absolute takeover of the kingdom that she believed she would rule.

The kingdom that she believed loved her Grandsire and her mother.

"The crown of the Conqueror passed down through generations," Ser Criston held up the crown before placing it on Aegon's head. Levana looked up at her husband who was watching the coronation with a scowl on his face.

"Love?" Levana whispered as Aemond turned to her. He held her hand again with a sigh, "I'm fine."

Levana knew that he wasn't but what could they do at the moment?

Ser Criston took a step back, before addressing the crowd:

Â 

Let the Seven bear witness that Aegon Targaryen is the true heir to the Iron Throne

Â 

There was silence in the crowd for a while as Aegon stood up. He looked at each of his family members who bowed to him. When his eyes landed on Levana, she just gave him a small smile.

"Levana," the Queen called as Aegon waited for the princess to bow but she stood there. The newly crowned King chuckled in amusement before waving his hand, "you never change."

"And I never will," Levana responded as Ser Criston cleared his throat before the High Septon addressed the crowd:

Â 

All hail His Grace, Aegon, Seco nd of His Name, King the Andals and the Rhoynar, and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms and Protector of the Realm.

Aegon the King!

Â 

The crowd began to cheer and clap as Aegon turned to them. With the newfound confidence that the crown bestowed on him, he took out Blackfyre and began to raise it in the air as the crown called for his name.

"Beware the beast beneath the boards," Levana heard Helaena whisper as she turned to her. Just before she could ask the other princess what she had meant, a loud roar came from below them, and from the ground emerged a dragon.

The crowd began to scramble in panic as Aemond wrapped his arm around Levana, holding her protectively as his other hand went to the hilt of his sword. Ser Criston ran to them to stand in Helena's defense as the dust disappeared to reveal Princess Rhaenys and Meleys.

The Hand repeatedly instructed the knights to open the doors as the Queen stood in front of Aegon.

The Red Queen approached the stage as Princess Rhaenys looked at Levana, her hand outstretched, "come with me!"

Levana looked at her grandmother and then at Aemond. Before she could respond, Meleyes let out a loud roar as Princess Rhaenys repeated, "Ana, come with me!"

The princess shook her head as the doors of the Dragonpit began to close. Princess Rhaenys posed a disappointed look on her face but was ultimately met with no choice but to instruct her dragon to leave. Meleys turned her back on them before spreading her wings and flying out of the stronghold.

"Eva!" The Dowager Queen approached Levana and held her shoulders, "did you know about this?!"

Levana looked at Alicent in disbelief and shook her head, "I was locked in my room, how could I have helped her?!"

"Take Princess Levana back to the Red Keep," Otto ordered, "it seems that we have a traitor within our midst."

"Do not touch my wife!" Aemond took out his sword as the knights started to approach them, "Aegon, do something!"

"Leave Princess Levana alone," Aegon stated, "there's no way it could've been her."

"Take them away," the Hand ordered but Aegon stepped in front of the guards, "I am the king now and what I say goes!"

The knights began to back away from them when Aegon turned to face Aemond and Levana, "you both owe me."

"Thank you, brother," Aemond muttered as Aegon glared at the Hand, "I want a list of which lords are here and aren't, find your traitor from that list but I will not have you blaming Princess Levana blindly."

"Thank you, Aegon," Levana whispered as Aemond escorted Levana away from the stage. Ser Nandor met them at the bottom of the stage and at the bottom of the steps to escort them away on their carriage.

Once they boarded the carriage, Levana let out a sigh of relief.

At the very least, Levana knew that her grandmother was out of harm's way for now.

ã€ğŸ“ğŸ‘ã€‘

The moment that they arrived at the Red Keep, knights approached to separate Levana from Aemond but the latter would not have it. He reminded them that no one was to touch them under King Aegon's orders and whoever shall lay their hands on his family would suffer the wrath of the prince.

This was able to ward off the knights who tried as much as to get near the prince and princess but it was not able to ward off the Hand of the King and the Queen who personally came to Levana's temporary confinement. Aemond was, in a word,Â forcedÂ to leave his wife behind. Aemond begrudgingly did what he was told and joined their children in the nursery.

"I don't suppose you know anything about your grandmother's escape, Princess Levana?" Otto asked but Levana refused to speak. She sat on her Grandsire's chair by the fireplace, opposite the Queen while the Hand stood by the door. The male sighed deeply, "it would be much easier if you admitted to anything that you might know."

"Didn't Aegon instruct that I was not to be accused of my grandmother's escape blindly?" Levana asked as the Dowager Queen sighed.

"It's not an accusation, Eva," Alicent stated but Levana raised a brow.

"Examine the Hand's question again, your Grace, he stated that it would be much easier if I admitted to what I might know, did he not?" Levana asked, "is that not an accusation as the Lord Hand already assumed that I had something to do with how Princess Rhaenys escaped?"

"Princess Levana," Alicent held the princess' hand, "do it for the sake of your children."

"What will you do to my children?" Levana's eyes shot wide, "are you going to take them from me?"

"Eva, that's not what I mea--"

"You'd do to my children the very same thing that my own mother did for me?" Levana asked, "Queen Alicent, for as long as I have resided in the Red Keep, I have stood by your side and that of Aemond's even to the distaste of my kin."

"Princess Levana," Otto called, "mind your words."

"Mind my words?" Levana huffed, "mind your own because I will not sit here, be threatened to lose my children, and be accused of an act of treason."

Alicent reached for Levana's hand and held it tightly, "Eva, know that I trust you; we are just doing this to maintain face."

"If you trust me, your Grace, then we wouldn't be in this position."

"Your hostility proves to me that you are guilty of the accusation," Otto stated but the Dowager Queen stood up and faced him, "the princess is hostile because you insist on accusing her of something that she has not done!"

"How can you continue to be so blind, Alicent?"Â Otto asked,Â "she's manipulated you."

"Blind?" Alicent hissed, "Levana is your grandson's wife and the mother of your grandchildren, you've treated her as if she was unwelcome in her own home!"

Just as Otto was about to reply, the doors burst open to reveal Aemond and Ser Nandor. The former immediately rushed to Levana's side and knelt down beside her, holding her hand in his. Meanwhile, Ser Nandor bowed to the royals in front of him, "permission to speak, your Graces?"

"Please do, Ser Nandor," Alicent stated as Ser Nandor faced the Dowager Queen, "it's been confirmed by Ser Arryk Cargyll that his brother, Ser Erryk, has escaped from King's Landing."

The Dowager Queen stood up, "he's defected from his duties?"

"The only other ship that left the port in the hours after King Aegon's coronation was headed for Dragonstone, your Grace," Ser Nandor stated as Alicent nodded and dismissed him. Ser Nandor bowed and left the room, closing the doors behind him as Alicent turned to Otto.

"You will apologize to Levana," Alicent stated, "you will apologize to the princess for the accusations that you have done."

Otto glared at the Dowager Queen before turning to face Levana and bowing his head, "my apologies, I may have been wrong about you, Princes Levana."

"May have been wrong?" Aemond repeated, "you were wrong about her, and yet you still believe that she helped Princess Rhaenys escape though there is enough proof that it wasn't her?"

"Aemond," the Dowager Queen called, "enough."

"Leave us," Aemond stated as the Hand nodded at the Dowager Queen who sighed and left the room. The Hand lingered for a few moments, watching Aemond and his wife before taking his leave as well, closing the doors behind him.

"Now, do you see?" Levana asked, "do you see why I wanted to leave?"

"I know, Eva," Aemond sighed as he leaned his forehead against his wife's stomach, "I'm sorry, I should have listened."

"Aemond, I don't know how much more of this I can take," Levana stated, "before you came, your mother hinted that they would involve our children in this and I don't want the both of them to suffer."

"They'll have to go through me," Aemond said, "I will not let anyone harm you."

"Aemond, you cannot keep on promising me this," Levana stated as she stood up from her seat, "you cannot keep on promising that we will be safe because we will never be!"

"Eva!"

"We will never be safe here, Aemond," Levana began, "not while you are married to me, the daughter of Rhaenyra Targaryen and a threat to Aegon's rule as king."

Aemond wrapped his arms around her, holding her close to him, "I'm waiting for the right time, Eva, we'll leave when the time is right."

"The time will never be right, Aemond," Levana sighed, "if a war is to begin and I am sure that it will, we will have no choice but to be a part of it."

"If your mother concedes and bends the knee, a war will not ensue," Aemond stated as his wife turned to him with disbelief on her face.

"You want my mother, the rightful heir, to bend the knee to a usurper?" Levana asked, "how dare you?"

"Eva, that's not what I meant."

"What else could you have meant, Aemond?"

"We can avoid war," Aemond sighed, "I can talk to mother and my Grandsire, we can fly to Dragonstone and you can convince her to bend the knee on your own."

"I will be doing no such thing," Levana smiled, "I would rather die than help this plot."

"You are being unreasonable," Aemond responded as the princess smiled at him.

"I'm the unreasonable one now?" Levana chuckled, "you were the one who insisted that we stayed though you promised that we would leave the instant that things went sour."

"Do you still hold that against me?"

"I will forever hold that against you because we would've been safer if we had left King's Landing," Levana stated, "until I am released from this room, IÂ willÂ hold it against you."Â 

ã€ğŸ“ğŸ’ã€‘

Princess Rhaenyra walked into the Grand Hall of Dragonstone where she found Lucerys, admiring The Painted Table. She took a deep breath before walking towards him, "there you are."

"The Sea Snake is going to die, isn't he?" Lucerys asked as his mother looked at him with worry, "Luke--"

"I can't be Lord of the Tides," Lucerys stated firmly, "Grandsire was the greatest sailor who ever lived and I get greensick before the ship even leaves the harbor!"

Rhaenyra listened to her son intently, watching him as she placed a hand on her stomach.

"I don't want Driftmark," Lucerys said, "it should've passed on Jace or even Ser Vaemond!"

"We do not choose your destiny, Luke," Rhaenyra sighed, "it chooses us."

"Grandsire let you choose whether you'd be his heir," Lucerys reasoned, "you told us so."

Rhaenyra placed a hand on the Painted Table before walking toward her son, "and do you want to know the truth of it?"

"I was frightened," Rhaenyra admitted, "I was four-and-ten, same as you are now, I wasn't ready to be the Queen of the Seven Kingdoms but it was my duty."

Lucerys looked at his mother with a look that was mixed with confusion and admiration.

"In time, I came to understand that I had to earn my inheritance," Rhaenyra smiled as Lucerys looked down, "I'm not like you."

"In what way, sweet boy?"

"I'm not perfect," Lucerys stated, "I'm not like you and Ana who are perfect to inherit the throne."

Rhaenya smiled and placed a kiss on her son's temple, holding him close to her, "your sister and I are anything but."

"Good morrow, Ser Lorent," Rhaenya turned to face the knight who bowed his head in respect.

"Princess Rhaenys has just arrived on dragonback," Ser Lorent informed, "she urgently requests an audience with you and Prince Daemon."

Hours after their argument, Levana and Aemond kept their distance from each other. While the latter tried his best to communicate with his wife and stay by her side, Levana ignored all his advances - serves him right for what he's decided to put his wife through.

Aemond was unsure at this point if his own wife still had trust in him. He knew, more than anything, that it would've taken brute force for his wife to even volunteer to be in the same room as Aegon's small council which left him wondering why she was so willing to even escort his Grandsire to Dragonstone.

Was she planning to defect right there?

He knew that she wouldn't because their children would still be in the Red Keep - unless she ordered someone to help them escape. Though, he did think this to be unlikely.

Aemond arrived at the Dragonpit just a few hours after their meeting to find his wife just beside her dragon. It's been months since he'd last seen her fly and he knows just how much she missed the feeling of it.

Vermithor must have sensed the tension between them as he growled when Aemond approached them. The dragon was just as angry to see him as his rider who glared at the approaching prince.

"You don't have to do this, Eva."

"I want to do it," Levana responded, "it'll take the attention from me for a while if I do this."

"How about our plan to leave?" Aemond asked, "are we no longer following that plot?"

"Partially," Aemond stated, "if you could escape, where would you go?"

"I hoped you would so I could follow you," Aemond stated, "I'm on your side, Eva."

"Is it true?"Â Rhaenyra asked,Â "are my grandchildren being held hostage by the Dowager Queen so you would do their bidding?"

Levana nodded,Â "as much as I want to do something about it, I have to be careful for the sake of my children."

"And your husband?"Â Daemon asked,Â "where does he stand in all of this?"

"My husband has told me numerous times that he would stand beside me,"Â Levana sighed,Â "though I have my doubts now."

"Do you still have allies in the Red Keep?"Â Rhaenyra asked,Â "you need not tell me who they are, just tell me if you have any left."

"I have one,"Â Levana stated,Â "I told my trusted handmaiden to leave before things got ugly."

"That's very kind of you, Ana,"Â Rhaenyra sighed,Â "but you have put yourself at such a disadvantage."

"I will send for my men from the City Watch to help you,"Â Daemon stated,Â "at the very least, they would be able to help you escape from the King's Landing."

"You do realize that conversing in your mother tongue in my presence is an act of treason?" Otto asked, "you'd do well to remember that."

Levana glared, "if I wanted you dead, Lord Hightower, you would know by now."

"Do not threaten me," Otto responded, "you do know have your children by the neck."

"Involving children, Otto?" Rhaenyra raised a brow, "that's inhumane, even for you."

"Princess Levana has been inducted to the King's Small Council," Otto announced, "the measures that we take simply are simply to ensure her loyalty to the Iron Throne."

Levana sighed, placing a hand on the dagger on her belt. Rhaenyra noticed this and gasped slightly - the dagger was very familiar to her.

"Where did you get that dagger?"Â Rhaenyra asked as Levana lifted her hand from the hilt,Â "it was from my grandsire, King Viserys."

"Why do you have it?"

"He gave it to me,"Â Levana stated,Â "he gave it to me on his deathbed."

"I've had enough of this," Otto interjected, "your response, Princess Rhaenyra?"

"King's Landing will have my answer on the morrow," Rhaenyra responded as she turned her back and began to make her way back into the palace.

Syrax flew just after her master left. Vermithor saw her off with a loud grumble before flying off. Levana knew that she would be getting a mouthful once she arrived back at the Red Keep - the Hand won't give her much peace after her conversation with her mother.

Levana and her dragon landed safely at the Dragonpit. As soon as she unmounted from Vermithor, the dragon made its way back into the pit and into its chambers - one that was constructed for him at the order of her grandsire.

The princess looked at her dragon as it left before turning to make her way back to her horse that waited for her arrival.

"How was it?"

Levana bore a look of shock at the sight of her husband, leaning against a carriage. She thought that he had already retreated to the palace after she flew off but as it turns out, he might have waited for her to return.

"Exhausting," Levana admitted, "I had half the mind to burn your grandsire and his entourage right then and there but I kept my ambitions to myself as I didn't want to bring harm to my children."

Aemond chuckled as he pushed himself away from the carriage to stand by the door, "speaking of our children," he said as he pulled the door open. Immediately, Aemma and Baelon ran out of the carriage and into their mother's arms. Levana smiled, embracing her children, it had been a while since she saw them last.

"How are my two little dragons?" Levana asked, "has your grandmother been treating you well?"

Aemma nodded, "we also get to play with our cousins!"

"Aunt Helaena plays with us too!" Baelon excitedly said as Levana listened to the eager stories from her children. Aemond watched as his wife's expression softened - a contrast to how hard she had looked in the past few days.

"Shall we head back to the Red Keep?" Aemond asked, "the four of us can spend time together in the Godswood, reading stories," he added, earning a smile from Levana. It had been a while since they were able to be in each other's company.

"I would like that very much," Levana smiled as she carried Baelon in her arms while Aemond took Aemma in hers.

The four would return to the Red Keep while the Hand and his entourage were still on their voyage. They would need to spend as much time together for the time that they had lost and possibly, for the time that they had left.

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Princess Rhaenys retreated to her husband's chambers after they were dismissed by the Black Queen from the Great Hall. She had spent many hours watching over him - so much so that she had fallen asleep on the chair beside his bed.

"I've had men whipped for falling asleep on their watch."

Princess Rhaenys was jolted awake by the sound of her husband's voice. She turned her head to face as the Sea Snake sighed.

"But you are no man."

"You abandoned me when I most needed you," Rhaenys began, "both our children were stolen from us and I needed you."

Lord Corlys turned his head but his Lady Wife would continue with her sentiments.

"Baela and Rhaena needed you but you abandoned us for more adventure at sea," Princess Rhaenys sighed as she reached for the cloth in a bowl of water, "as has always been your way."

"I had no other place to turn," Lord Corlys confessed, "I lost everything."

"We lost, Corlys,"Â Rhaenys interjected,Â "we,"Â she repeated before taking a seat by his bedside to run the wet cloth by his hands.

"I understand we have a new king," Lord Corlys sighed.

"The Stranger casts a long shadow over this family," Rhaenys sighed as she placed the cloth on her husband's forehead, "your brother is also dead."

Lord Corlys tried to sit up abruptly upon hearing the news but his wife kept a hand on his chest to keep him from exhausting his body more.

"In his haste to bury you and claim your seat, he stood before the King and denounced Laenor's sons as illegitimate," Rhaenys narrated, "Daemon took his head for it."

The Sea Snake huffed, "heedless ambition has always been a Velaryon weakness," he admitted before turning back to face the princess, "you were right, Rhaenys, I reached too far and for nothing."

The princess listened on as her husband took her hand in his, "our pursuit of the Iron Throne is at an end and we shall declare for no one."

Princess Rhaenys shook her head.

"We shall retire to High Tide to be content with our grandchildren and--"

"Ana, Jace, Luke, and Joff, are claimants to the throne," Rhaenys reminded, "they will not be safe so long as Aegon is king."

"Where is Ana?" Lord Corlys asked, "is our granddaughter in Dragonstone?"

Rhaeys shook her head, "she stayed in the Red Keep so I could escape."

Lord Corlys glared, "Rhaenyra has gone too far with allowing Levana to stay in the Red Keep and she was complicit in our son's death."

Princess Rhaenys took a deep breath as Lord Corlys gritted his teeth, "that girl ruins everything she touches."

"Coryls, that girl is holding the realm together at present."

The Sea Snake looked at his wife with a curious expression as Princess Rhaenys continued, "every man standing at the Painted Table urges her to plunge the realm into war and she's the only one who has demonstrated restraint."

"What would you have me do, Rhaenys?"

The princess sighed, "the right thing, Corlys."Â 

ã€ğŸ“ğŸ–ã€‘

The day after the encounter at Dragonstone was hectic, to say the least.

The princess was removed from her husband and children's presence to be locked up in her grandsire's room. Otto described it as a "punishment" for planning treason with her mother.

Aemond was, of course, angry - very angry to the point that he took his complaints directly to his brother, the king. Aegon had his doubts, of course, but he decided to hear the story from Levana herself. This led to their meeting which wasn't as productive as Aegon thought.

The moment Levana took her seat at the table, she was bombarded by accusations from the Hand and the members of the small council - particularly Tyland Lannister who seemed to fully agree with what Otto was saying.

Queen Alicent placed her hands on her forehead before slamming her hands on the table,Â "leave Princess Levana alone!"

Dowager Queen Alicent's raised voice was enough to bring the entire room to silence as Aemond walked beside his wife's chair, placing a hand on her shoulder as Aegon looked at them, "just tell us what you were talking about with your mother, sister," he sighed, "get this over with."

"I told you," Levana responded, "it's a matter that doesn't concern any of you."

"Were you plotting against the King, Princess?" Tyland raised a brow, "for what reason can you not tell us what you and your mother conversed about in High Valyrian in front of the Hand?"

Levana placed a hand on her stomach, "we were talking about my pregnancy," she lied, "as you all might remember, I am with child."

"For what reason do we have to believe you?" Tyland raised a brow.

Levana looked at him and then at Aegon, "Your Grace, is this the type of company that you would want in your small council?"

"You forget yourself, Lord Tyland," Aegon leaned against his seat, "do remember that Princess Levana is of House Targaryen and she is to be treated with respect despite the unproven claims that the Hand and Cole make of her."

"Her mother threatens to take the throne," Tyland continued, "and yet she is present at your Small Council."

"She is my sister by marriage and my niece, mind you," Aegon responded, "she is well-versed in matters that concern the realm and she is a dragonrider, you are a Lannister with a Fleet that can be taken down by Vermithor's flames."

Tyland looked at his lap in silence.

"Know your place, Lord Tyland," Aegon stated, "that goes for you all."

"Aegon, stop it," Alicent sighed as the King turned to her.

"The next person that tries to question Princess Levana and her loyalty to the throne over baseless claims will answer to myself and the Conqueror's sword," Aegon hissed, "do you understand?"

Those present at the King's Small Council could only nod. Aegon wasn't normally this serious but as he has grown to be fond of Levana - it was only expected that he would be taking her side.

"No more questions of Princess Levana's loyalty," Aegon repeated, "her family and that of my brother will be under my protection and if they are so much as threatened, I will have somebody's head on a spike for it."

The Hand cleared his throat, "there is a matter of our allies to be discussed, your Grace," he began to avoid the topic, "we need to secure our allies as most of the Lords of the Seven Kingdoms swore fealty to Princess Rhaenyra when she was named heir."

"We have House Strong," Alicent stated, "I shall have a word with Lord Larys when I see him next."

For a moment, Levana felt her heart drop - she clutched the fabric of her dress before looking over at Ser Nandor who gave her a nod of assurance. The princess smiled before looking up at her husband who listened intently to the conversation.

"House Baratheon might need more convincing," the Hand stated as he turned to Aemond, "Prince Aemond, fly to Storm's End to secure the support of Lord Borros Baratheon."

Aemond nodded but as he was about to leave, he was stopped by the Dowager Queen who turned to Levana, "the princess will join you."

"She's with child!" Aemond responded, "I will not risk it."

"Princess Levana is a Baratheon by her grandmother, Princess Rhaenys," Alicent stated, "it would only be appropriate that she would be the one to treat with her granduncle."

"I will refuse on my wife's behalf," Aemond stated, "she's already been on dragonback and even the short journey to Dragonstone proved to exert much effort for her."

"You will be with her," Otto reasoned, "you can keep an eye on her."

"You forget that her pregnancy is at risk as it is," Aemond reasoned, "remember that she already bled in the past and I will not put my wife and child at risk."

"Let it go, Aemond," Levana sighed as she stood up from her seat, the prince placed a hand around her waist to help her maintain balance, "let's just get this over with."

The two left the room with Ser Nandor in tow. The knight kept his distance from the both of them, allowing Aemond to whisper words of assurance to his wife.

"It will be a quick trip, I promise," Aemond assured.

"It's not the length of the trip that I am worried about, Aemond," Levana sighed, "it's the fact that my mother will also surely send an envoy to Storm's End and it might be one of my brothers."

"I vow to behave."

"I hardly doubt it."

"Eva," Aemond sighed, "please trust me."

"Aemond, my love," Levana looked up at him, "I do but as you know, things have not been the same since Aegon's coronation and my heart trusts you, my husband, but I cannot bring my mind to do the same."

Aemond would be lying if he said that his wife's words cut through him like a knife. It was one thing that they were trying to fix whatever rift they had but to have confirmation from her that she no longer fully trusted in him was another. It felt as though a sword had been driven through his chest - though, his wife's lack of trust in him proved to hurt much more than the wound from a sword.

"We'll leave the message at Storm's End and leave immediately after the formalities," Aemond sighed, "I will not question it and if we were to encounter any of your brothers, I would leave it at that."

"Do you swear it?" Levana asked as Aemond smiled slightly, placing his hands on either side of Levana's stomach. He knelt in front of her, placing a kiss on her stomach. He leaned his forehead on her stomach and sighed, "I swear it."

"You better make good on your promise," Levana sighed, "at least, this one."

Aemond looked up at his wife and nodded sadly. He knew he had disappointed her too much now.

"Your Graces," Ser Nandor approached them with a scroll, "the message for you to deliver to Storm's End has arrived."

The prince took a scroll in his hand before standing up straight. He held Levana's hand in his and placed a kiss on her knuckles.

"Let's be off, my love."

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

Â 

Rhaenyra sat by her Painted Table, there was so much on her mind that she didn't bother listening to the conversations of the lords who stood by her. Her mind was clouded with many questions but the most important one was why her father gave Levana Aegon the Conqueror's dagger when he had named her heir.

Does that mean that she was now the true heir to the Iron Throne and not her?

Has she been deposed by her daughter?

"The Lord of the Tides, Lord Corlys Velaryon, and his wife, Princess Rhaenys Targaryen."

Rhaenyra immediately stood up from her seat and stood in attention to welcome the Lord who walked slowly down the steps with his wife and grandchildren.

"My lords," Corlys acknowledged the others as Rhaenys stood by his side. Baela and Rhaena would proceed to stand by their betrothed on the other end of the table.

"Lord Corlys," Rhaenyra greeted, "it brings much relief to see you here and healthy again."

Lord Corlys nodded, "I'm very sorry about your father, princess," he bowed his head slightly, "he was a good man."

At that, the Lord of the Tides directed his attention to the others present in the room, "where is Daemon?"

"There are other concerns that demanded the prince's attention," Rhaenyra responded as Lord Corlys hummed in acknowledgment before glancing over the Painted Table, "your declared allies?"

"Yes--"

"Too few to win a war for the throne."

Rhaenyra was taken aback, "well, we would also hope to have the support of Houses Arryn, Baratheon, and Stark."

"Hope is the fool's ally," Lord Corlys stated.

"Both Arryn and Baratheon share a blood with my House," Rhaenyra pointed out, "but all of them swore oaths to me."

"As did House Hightower."

"As did you, Lord Corlys."

Lord Corlys turned to his wife, "Houses Baratheon and Arryn also share a blood with someone who is still in King's Landing," he responded, "Levana still stands as their only way to secure the support of those Houses."

"I acknowledge that," Rhaenyra stated, "we are presently thinking of a way to help my daughter escape from King's Landing."

"It is my very hope that my granddaughter is retrieved," Corlys stated as Rhaenyra nodded, "she is our priority."

The Lord of the Tides nodded before glancing at the Painted Table once more, "your father's realm was one of justice and honor," he began, "our Houses are bound by common blood and common cause."

Lord Corlys then turned toward the other lords, "this Hightower treason cannot stand," he stated, "you have the full support of our fleet and House, your Grace," he said before bowing his head to his Queen.

"You honor me, Lord Corlys," Rhaenyra stated before turning her head to face the other princess, "Princess Rhaenys."

The Black Queen took a deep breath, "but, as I said to my bannermen, I made a promise to my father to hold the realm strong and united," she said firmly, "if war's first stroke is to fall, it will not be by my hand."

"You do not mean to act?" Lord Corlys asked with a confused expression.

"Taking caution does not mean standing fast," Rhaenyra explained, "I wish to know who my allies are before I send them to war."

Lord Corlys approached the Queen, "the consequence of my near demise at the Stepstones is that we now control them," he said proudly, "I took care to fully garrison the territory this time and a total blockade of the shipping lanes will be in place in days, if not already," he continued.

Rhaenyra listened intently to what the Lord of the Tides has accomplished. In her mind, this was a strong lead to counter their enemies.

"The Triarchy have been routed and the Narrow Sea is ours," Lord Corlys stated, "if we further seal the Gullet, we can cut off all seaborn travel and trade to King's Landing."

"I shall take Meleys and patrol the Gullet myself," Princess Rhaenys said with a small smile.

"When we drain the Narrow Sea, we can surround King's Landing, lay siege to the Red Keep, and force the Greens' surrender," Lord Bartimos Celtigar stated as Rhaenyra looked down at the Painted Table, thinking about what she would tell her council next.

"If we are to have enough swords to surround King's Landing, we must first secure the support of Winterfell, the Eyrie, and Storm's End," Rhaenyra stated, placing her hands on the Painted Table as she further observed the map.

"I'll prepare the ravens, your Grace," Maester Gerardys stated as the Queen nodded.

"We should bear those messages."

Almost too quickly, Rhaenyra's head snapped toward the direction of her son who turned to his younger brother. Jacaerys took a deep breath, "dragons can fly faster than ravens and they're more convincing," he said as Lucerys gave him a small nod.

"Send us," Jacaerys offered as Lord Corlys turned to Rhaenyra, "the prince is right, your Grace."

"Very well," Rhaenyra conceded. The prince looked at his mother with a serious expression as the Queen smiled slightly.

"Prince Jacaerys will fly north," she instructed, "first to the Eyrie to see my mother's cousin, the Lady Jeyne Arryn," she continued, "then to Winterfell to treat with Lord Cregan Stark for the support of the North."

Jacaerys nodded as Rhaenyra turned to her younger son, Lucerys, who stood in attention.

"Prince Lucerys will fly south to Storm's End and treat with Lord Borros Baratheon," Rhaenyra stated, "we must remind these lords of the oaths they swore and the cost of breaking them."

ã€ğŸ“ğŸ—ã€‘

Rhaenyra watched the open sea with Ser Erryk by her side. Her sons would be flying to treat with the lords and ladies that she hopes would become their allies - she knew that they would be able to accomplish such feats but her heart was filled with worry for them still.

Jacaerys and Lucerys approached their mother. Both princes' were dressed in riding gear with a sword strapped to their waists. They bore the sigil of House Targaryen on their chest as well as the colors of the banners that they fly.Â 

Rhaenyra turned to her sons with scrolls in her hands, "it's been said that as Targaryens, we are closer to gods than to men," she chuckled slightly, "the Iron Throne puts us a touch closer, perhaps."

â”â”â”â” â—¦ â– â—¦â”â”â”â”

The journey to Stormâ€™s End proved to be easy enough for Aemond, Vhagar, and Vermithor - though, Levana was already starting to feel the effects of her pregnancy. She wasnâ€™t as alert as sheâ€™d like and she wasnâ€™t as fast as she liked - maybe it was the sign of an impending storm that made her lethargic but Aemond tried his best to fly by her side, much to the distaste of Vermithor who repeatedly tried to attack Vhagar.Â 

Levana and Aemond arrived just before the first drops of rain. Aemond unmounted from Vhagar first so he could help Levana unmount from her own dragon. â€œI am Prince Aemond Targaryen,â€ Aemond began, â€œmy wife, Princess Levana, and I are here to deliver a message to Lord Borros from the king.â€Â

Despite the proud aura that the prince had about him, he - for the first time in a long time - was nervous to face the lord. â€œPrincess Levana Velaryon and Prince Aemond of House Targaryen,â€ one of the squires announced as Levana and Aemond made their way into the Great Hall of Storm's End where Lord Borros sat on a throne in the center.Â

â€œThe last time that we saw each other was at your wedding,â€ Lord Borros stated, â€œthat was some three or four years ago?â€Â 

â€œthree, granduncle,â€ Levana stated, â€œour children are just about the same age.â€Â 

â€œSplendid,â€ Lord Borros chuckled, â€œI understand that you are with child and yet you traveled to treat with me, I am honored.â€Â

â€œMaester,â€ Lord Borros called as one of his maesters quickly approached Aemond who handed him the scroll. The maester scrambled to open it, quickly reading its contents before walking up to Lord Borros and whispering the contents to him.Â 

â€œWhat do you have to give me in return?â€ Lord Borros asked, â€œgrandniece, you surely do not expect me to give my support to the king without an exchange.â€Â

â€œI was to propose a marriage pact,â€ the Baratheon ruler turned to his daughter, â€œthough, I am quite certain that it will put me at a disadvantage with the king and my own grandniece.â€Â 

Levana smiled at the comment as Aemond squeezed her hand tightly. The princess looked up at the prince who had a small smile on his face as if he was saying that getting the support of House Baratheon would come easily.Â 

â€œTake one of my daughters as a mistress, Prince Aemond,â€ Lord Borros spoke suddenly. The request look the couple by surprise as the Baratheon chuckled loudly, â€œas my daughters would not be able to marry the prince, a mistress would be second best, donâ€™t you think?â€Â 

â€œDo you jest, granduncle?â€ Levana asked in disbelief, â€œmy husband is an honorable man.â€Â 

â€œYouâ€™re pregnant,â€ Lord Borros pointed out, â€œhe would need someone by his side to satisfy his urges,â€ he continued, adding stress to his last word.

Levana turned to her husband who gritted his teeth in response.Â 

â€œWhat say you, Prince Aemond?â€Â 

Aemond was silent. If he were to give an answer, that would put him in a pinch either way. Instead, he turned to his wife. Levana's other hand was balled into a fit and she was squeezing his hand tightly, so much so that the prince couldâ€™ve sworn that his hand had grown numb.Â 

â€œIf you come to me empty-handed, I cannot give you my support,â€ Lord Borros responded, â€œIâ€™m sure you would understand, grandniece.â€Â 

Levanaâ€™s ears perked up, â€œLord Borros, I will say it again, my husband is an honorable man and for you to even offer the thought of granting him a mistress puts your daughters, your own blood, in a humiliating position.â€Â 

â€œMarriage is what they are good for,â€ Lord Borros responded, â€œa prince of the realm steps into my home, requesting my loyalty, and I would be an imbecile if I did not take this to my advantage.â€

The princess chuckled before letting go of her husbandâ€™s hand. She slowly walked to her granduncle, a sheepish smile on her face. She was only a few steps away from the seat when she stopped. She looked at her second cousins with a small smile before turning her attention back to Lord Borros who looked at her with a puzzled expression, â€œwhat is this, Princess Levana?â€Â 

â€œGranduncle, I ride Vermithor,â€ Levana stated, â€œthe mount of King Jahaerys, and it would be pitiful if his flames were used on somebody like you.â€Â 

â€œPardon, Princess Levana?â€ Lord Borros chuckled, â€œyou are in my Houseâ€™s seat and home!â€Â 

â€œIt wonâ€™t be your seat for much longer if I decide to have my dragon burn Stormâ€™s End to ashes,â€ Levana stated, â€œnow would it, granduncle?â€Â 

â€œWhy are you threatening me?!â€Â 

Screw the support that they needed from the Baratheons. She was not about to let anyone talk about her marriage that way â€” not when it was already in disarray.Â 

â€œHave you no regard for your own daughters?â€ Levana asked, â€œhave you no respect for my marriage?â€Â 

â€œYou are asking for my support!â€Â 

â€œAnd I can force you into it if I wanted to,â€ Levana responded as a loud roar echoed through the halls of Stormâ€™s End, â€œmy dragon is one of the largest dragons alive, Lord Borros, and he can easily take all of you down should you decide to disrespect my marriage and your daughters again.â€Â 

Levana's blood boiled. She always thought of Lord Borros as honorable but the encounter proved everything but that.

Lord Borros was taken aback. He had always thought of his grandniece as someone who was demure and softspoken - this was the first time that he had seen her in such a fit of rage that it sent a shiver down his spine. Almost immediately, he got off his chair, raised his hands, and bent the knee. The members of his court and his children followed his actions, bending the knee as Levana looked around her.

At the realization of what she had just done, Levana felt disgusted - never in her life did she imagine that she would be using her own dragon as an instrument of fear. A part of her believed that Lord Borros absolutely deserved the venom in her words but there was also a part that believed that she may have gone too far.Â 

Aemond approached his wife, wrapping an arm around her waist before pressing a kiss against her temple, â€œthat was well done,â€ he whispered as he escorted her back to the center of the room.Â 

Lord Borros stood up slowly, his hands still raised. He looked at his grandniece with fear before chuckling nervously, â€œlet us prepare a feast for my grandniece and her husband,â€ he stated, â€œa token of a deal well struck.â€Â 

The knights and attendees quickly scrambled out of the room. Lord Borrosâ€™ daughters walked in front of Levana, bowing their hands in gratitude before leaving the Great Hall as well.Â 

â€œFollow me,â€ Lord Borros gestured toward one of the doors, walking toward it. Levana and Aemond followed after him.Â 

â€œWas that jealousy speaking?â€ Aemond whispered as Levana turned to face him, â€œno, it was my annoyance for his disrespect.â€Â 

â€œShame,â€ the prince chuckled, â€œthere is a certain attractiveness about you when you look jealous.â€Â 

â€œDo not get used to it, Aemond,â€ Levana hissed. The prince let out another chuckle as they continued to follow behind Lord Borros.Â 

The princess walked beside her husband in silence as the latter conversed with Lord Borros about matters of the realm. She was disgusted by what she had just done and debated whether this was worth whatever she was fighting for. Of course, her children were her first priority and above all else, she was doing this for them - playing along with the desires of the Hand and the Dowager Queen so she could keep her children safe.

But just how long could she keep this up?

ã€ğŸ”ğŸã€‘

Levana felt uneasy throughout the entire feast. She felt nauseous and couldn't bear to eat at all. This didn't go unnoticed by her husband who sat by her side, holding her hand. He first noticed that his wife hardly touched the food that he had given her. He became more worried when the princess' breathing became labored.

Aemond alerted Lord Borros at once. The Baratheon was quick to rally his maesters to help take Levana to one of the rooms in the castle.

Lord Borros had the maesters attend to the princess before retreating back to the Great Hall with his daughters. Meanwhile, Aemond watched his wife from the door. He blamed his mother for forcing her to go through this but he also knew that the reason why his wife might've wanted to come was to prevent him from fighting with her brothers - should he encounter them.

One of the knights alerted Prince Aemond that another dragon has been spotted flying toward the castle. He smiled slightly, excusing himself before heading to the Great Hall. He stopped by one of the doors to see that one of his nephews have indeed come to Storm's End.

"Prince Lucerys Velaryon, son of Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen."

For now, at least, Aemond and Lord Borros would be able to face the young prince without the supervision of the princess.

"Lord Borros," Lucerys greeted, "I brought you a message from my mother, the Queen."

Lord Borros huffed, "yet earlier today, I received an envoy from the King," he responded. Aemond took this as his signal to emerge from where he was standing. His presence shocked the young prince yet Lucerys stood strong.

"Is it King or Queen?" Lord Borros asked, "the House of the Dragon seems to not know who rules it," he chuckled before leaning forward.

"What's your mother's message?"

Lucerys held out a scroll and a knight took it. He delivered it to Lord Borros who immediately summoned a maester. Just as he did with the message from King Aegon, the maester read the contents of the scroll and whispered it to the Lord of Storm's End.

"Remind me of my father's oath?" Lord Borros asked quite angrily, "King Aegon was at least able to prove to me the might that he possessed."

Lucerys took a small step back.

"My sword and banners for the safety of my House," Lord Borros boasted, "if I do as your mother bids, would you wed one of my daughters, boy?"

"My lord, I'm not free to marry," Lucerys said, "I'm already betrothed."

"So you come to me with empty hands," Lord Borros hissed, "go home, pup, and tell your mother that the Lord of Storm's End is not her dog that she can whistle up at need to bait her foes."

Lucerys nodded, "I shall take your answer to the Queen, my lord," Lucerys stated before turning his back. The young prince began his walk out of the Great Hall with the message from Lord Borros.

"Wait."

Prince Lucerys stopped in his tracks to face Aemond who looked at him with a wicked smile, "my Lord Strong."

The younger of the two princes stepped back as Aemond chuckled, "did you really think that you could just fly about the realm trying to steal my brother's throne at no cost?"

"I will not fight you."

Aemond took a step closer to him.

"I came as a messenger," Lucerys declared, "not a warrior."

"A fight would be little challenge," Aemond stated as he proceeded to take off his eyepatch to reveal a sapphire where his eye would be. Lucerys gulped as he clutched the hilt of his sword tightly.

"I want you to put out your eye," Aemond demanded, "as payment for mine."

"Where is Ana?" Lucerys asked, "I saw Vermithor outside!"

"One will serve," Aemond ignored the younger prince as he threw his dagger toward the younger prince, "I will not blind you."

"Where is my sister?" Lucerys asked again but his questions fell on deaf ears.

"I plan to make a gift of it to my mother."

"No," Lucerys answered firmly.

"Then you are craven as well as a traitor," Aemond said in response.

"Not here!" Lord Borros raised his voice.

"Give me your eye or I will take it, bastard!" Aemond shouted as he walked towards Lucerys, picking up his dagger as he did so. The younger prince drew his sword as Lord Borros stood up from his seat.

"Not in my hall!" Lord Borros shouted, "the boy came as an envoy and I'll not have bloodshed beneath my roof," he continued before turning to one of the guards, "take Prince Lucerys back to his dragon, now!"

Aemond, for a moment, forgot his vow to his wife and decided that he would go out and mount Vhagar. The prince would command his dragon to fly; hiding in the clouds to wait for its prey.

Meanwhile, the princess sat up abruptly. She heard the unmistakable bellows of Vhagar from a distance even in the heavy rain. Concerned, she decided to peek out the window from the room where she was to spot her younger brother, Lucerys, running to his own dragon.

Her heart dropped.

Levana immediately rushed out of the room and to the Great Hall where Lord Borros was seated.

"My brother was here and no one bothered to inform me?!" Levana asked, "where is Prince Aemond?"

"The prince left on his dragon," Lord Borros stated, "he said that he would return for you."

Levana grunted as she made her way out of the hall, Lord Borros watching her as she left - he's definitely done something wrong.

"Lucerys!" Levana shouted but the prince had already commanded its dragon to fly off, "Luke!" she shouted again in the hopes of having a loud enough voice for her brother to hear her but it was to no avail. She gritted her teeth before rushing to her own mount.

Vermithor was restless. Either it was because of the rain or it was because of his rider's own uneasiness - one wouldn't know. Levana ran a hand through her dragon's neck in an attempt to soothe it.

"Please, Vermithor,"Â Levana breathed as tears started to pool in her eyes,Â "we have to catch up to Lucerys,"Â she pleaded as her dragon grumbled. The princess mounted her dragon, ignoring the heavy drops of rain and once she was seated on her saddle, Vermithor spread his wings and shot up into the sky.

The princess already knew what was bound to happen.

For the first time in her life, Levana felt as though time was finally her enemy - she was in a race against it to find either her husband or her brother.

She needed to stop her husband but more than anything, she needed to save her younger brother.

Levana needed to stop her husband.

ã€ğŸ”ğŸã€‘

[Italicized text denotes High Valyrian]

Lucerys held onto the reigns of his dragon for dear life. The rain was hard and he knew that Aemond was out there - hiding. He wanted to avoid the other prince as much as possible so he tried to fly relatively low, he knew that Vhagar wouldn't pass that low which would mean that he would be safer.

Still, the distant roars of another dragon and the lack of visibility made him nervous. His heart thumped loudly against his chest as he looked up - instinct made him do so as he felt something was above them.

Nothing was there except for the clouds.

The prince thought that he was safe until Vhagar intercepted their path by flying in front of them. Lucerys commanded his dragon to turn to the other side to avoid a collision. The task proved to be hard on both of them as Arrax was also just as uneasy.

Prince Aemond's laugh resonated loudly through the rain.

Lucerys took a deep breath as he turned his head to find Prince Aemond and Vhagar just behind him - catching up with them.

"Quickly, turn!"Â Lucerys commanded as Arrax tried his best to follow his rider's commands. They found themselves flying closer to the sea and into a few rock formations - an attempt to shake off the other prince from their trail.

Aemond laughed, flying above the trenches, looking for them.

"You owe a debt, boy,"Â Aemond called out.

"No, Arrax!"

Aemond turned his head to see the flames from Arrax's mouth collide with his dragon. This was enough to send Vhagar into a frenzy.

"No, Arrax, serve me!"

The older prince heard the pleas of his nephew as his own dragon began to shake angrily, "no, no, no, no, Vhagar!"

Aemond tried pulling on the reigns tightly, "serve me, Vhagar!" He commanded but his dragon wouldn't budge.

"Serve me, Vhagar!"

Just as Vhagar opened its mouth to catch Arrax, a wave of bronze was able to intercept the much larger dragon.

"Eva?" Aemond shouted, "what are you doing here?!"

Lucerys looked back, "Ana!"

The princess turned to her husband,Â "what are you doing?!"

"It's just harmless fun!"

"You made a vow, Aemond!"Â Levana shouted. But just as she was to give her husband another word, Vhagar hit Vermithor with her wings. This made the Bronze Fury fly farther from the prince.

"Vhagar, no!"Â Levana pleaded,Â "serve, Vhagar!"

The larger dragon seemed to stop for a while. Vhagar turned in Levana's direction, her eyes looking into the princess' as if she were in a trance. The interaction stunned Aemond, who loosened his hold on the reigns.

"How did you do that?"

"Ana!" Lucerys shouted again, "where are you?!"

Vhagar snapped out of its daze to pursue the younger prince once again.

"Vhagar, no!"Â Levana shouted as Vermithor began to fly faster in another attempt to intercept Vhagar or at least catch up with Lucerys.

Vhagar disappeared into the clouds as Levana saw that her brother managed to escape from the storm. There was a wave of relief that washed through Levana's chest as she managed to catch up with her brother.

"Ana!" Lucerys said happily albeit still frantic and what just happened, "I knew you were in Storm's-"

Levana's eyes widened.

She shrieked.

The princess didn't even have a chance to blink when Vhagar had Arrax between her teeth.

"Lucerys!" Levana shouted loudly as she commanded her dragon to fly toward the sea. She was sobbing but she needed to retrieve her younger brother's body before it fell into the sea. The princess kept her arms open as Vermithor managed to avoid Arrax's falling body; the prince's body fell into Levana's arms as the princess tried her best to keep him awake.

"Luke?" Levana held his cheek, patting it, "Lucerys, please wake up," she pleaded as the prince slowly and weakly opened his eyes.

"Ana?" Lucerys coughed, "why are you crying?"

Levana quickly directed her dragon to land on one of the islands by Storm's End. Vermithor lowered his body so that his rider could unmount him. The princess knelt by the sand, holding her brother close to her as she sobbed.

"I'm going to take you to King's Landing," Levana choked on a sob, "the maesters are going to help you and you're going to be alright, I promise," she cried frantically as Lucerys shook his head.

"We should go home, Ana," Lucerys coughed blood, "mother wants to see you and our brothers too," he added.

Levana continued to cry as the younger prince held up his hand to touch his sister's cheek, "how are Baelon and Aemma?"

"They're doing well, Luke," Levana managed to say, "they ask for their uncles all the time."

"I miss them too," Lucerys responded weakly, "maybe after this, I can go see them, yes?"

The princess nodded as Aemond landed a few meters away from them. The blonde prince unmounted from his dragon and approached his wife. Vermithor, however, greeted the prince with a loud snarl, keeping him away.

"Ana, will you tell them that I love them?" Lucerys asked, "tell Baelon and Aemma that they have uncles who love them very much?"

"I will," Levana nodded, "I will, Luke."

The prince smiled as Levana held him tighter. She knew that even though she would be able to fly back to King's Landing, she wouldn't be able to save her younger brother. The wound that he had suffered from Vhagar was too great - so much so that the blood from it stained much of Levana's clothes.

"Will you sing to me, Ana?" Lucerys requested, "the lullaby that you used to sing for me and Jace?"

"Of course," Levana smiled slightly, "I will."

Lucerys nodded and wiped the tear from Levana's cheek with his thumb, "that's my favorite lullaby especially when you sing it."

Levana chuckled as she held her brother's hand tightly in hers, she began to sing:

"I didn't want this, Eva!"

"How could you not want it?!" Levana raised her voice, "I heard you when I was chasing after the both of you, you said that he owed you a debt."

Aemond took a step back.

"Has the debt been paid, Aemond?" Levana asked, "my brother's life for your eye?!"

The prince was silent, "I didn't want this."

"I know that you didn't but you had a choice," Levana stated, "at the end of the day, it was your choice, and losing control of Vhagar is a blessing to you because now you don't have to suffer the blame of killing Prince Lucerys."

Aemond felt the coldness in his wife's words as Vermithor began to spread its wings.

"You've begun the war that my mother is trying so hard to avoid," Levana gritted her teeth,Â "I hope you're proud, Aemond,"Â she hissed before Vermithor shot up into the sky.

Aemond was stunned.

His wife was right.

He had begun the Dance of Dragons.

ã€ğŸ”ğŸ‘ã€‘- ğ­ğ°.

Chapter Notes

TRIGGER WARNING: Violence, murder, and mentions of abuse; DISCRETION IS ADVISED.

[Italicized text denotes Valyrian speech]

Â 

Levana's plans to escape from King's Landing were put in motion as soon as Ser Nandor received correspondence from House Greyjoy. Galatea assured them that her House would be in full support of Princess Levana and volunteered to help them make the escape.Â 

It was decided that they would be heading to the Iron Islands instead of Dragonstone. As much as Levana wanted to go home, she wasn't so sure if she would still be welcome there when it was her husband that sent Lucerys to the pyre.Â 

The princess kept her children in the dark with what they were about to do. They still spent time with the Dowager Queen and the last thing that Levana wanted was for her children to expose their plot.Â 

Maester Priamos also sent word in advance to Lady Nesrin Strong that they would be delivering her older brother to them within a few days time. She wasn't so sure what she would do with support from House Strong but at the very least, she would have allies.Â 

It's been five days since Lucerys' death and Princess Levana was restless.Â 

Apart from planning their escape, Levana spent most of her sleepless nights in the company of her Grandsire's sculptures. She spent hours cleaning them and even changing the positions of certain figures. It didn't do much but it did provide her with a way to clear her mind.Â 

During those days, Helaena would come visit them with her own children. Baelon and Aemma had grown close to their cousins: Jaehaerys, Jaehera, and Maelor â€” it was a welcome sight. On some nights, they would also visit the Dowager Queen in her residence at the Tower of the Hand.Â 

More than anything, Levana was glad that she was allowed out of her confinement. It did well for the children as they would stop asking to see their father from time to time.Â 

Aemond kept his distance from them. As he wasn't allowed to see them, the prince would stay content with being able to watch them from afar. Aemma and Baelon would wave at him every now and then but they are constantly reminded that they weren't allowed to approach their father for the time being.Â 

It pained Levana to see her children in dismay when they couldn't even embrace their father. She knew that they must miss him.Â 

She did too.Â 

"We're leaving tomorrow night," Ser Nandor stated, "everything is set and Maester Priamos has left in advance with Vad and Lord Larys, they should be on their way to Harrenhal as we speak."Â 

Levana nodded at the report, "at least we'd have Harrenhal and House Strong for now."Â 

"I've also sent word to Dorne," Ser Nandor reported, "I have yet to receive a reply from Prince Sorin but he usually prefers words than actions."Â 

"You're fond of each other," Levana smiled, "aren't you?"Â 

"Like you wouldn't believe, Your Grace," Ser Nandor chuckled.Â 

Ser Nandor kept no secrets from the princess. She knew that Prince Sorin and him were very close â€” their relationship reminded Levana of her father and Ser Qarl.Â 

Sometimes, she wondered what her father would do given the situation. Though, she believed that, if Ser Laenor were alive, they would be in the safety of High Tide by now.Â 

"Which handmaids are coming with us, Princess Levana?"Â 

"Well, we need to bring at least two nurses for the children and at least two handmaidens would do," Levana responded, "you're good at seeing through people so I will leave that to you."Â 

Ser Nandor bowed his head as the door opened to reveal Helaena with the children.Â 

"Queen Helaena," Ser Nandor greeted as Baelon and Aemma ran into the room to take their mother by her hands.

"It's time to visit grandma!" Aemma said excitedly as Levana stood up from her seat. The princess nodded at Ser Nandor who did the same.Â 

"Sister," Helaena smiled, "how are you?"Â 

"It could be much worse," Levana responded, "but I feel that things will start getting better soon."Â 

"I do hope so," Helaena responded as the children walked ahead of them. This allowed the two females to have a few moments to themselves.Â 

"Aemond misses you," Helaena whispered, "sometimes, I see him standing in front of your door," she added.Â 

"I miss him just as much," Levana confessed, "but our time apart has allowed me to reflect about our marriage and what has happened thus far."Â 

"He stopped flying, you know," Helaena sighed, "the King orders him to go on patrols but he never takes Vhagar anymore."Â 

"He goes on horseback?"Â 

"Sometimes it's horseback but sometimes he also commands the fleet," Helaena smiled, "I don't think he's been to the Dragonpit since the incident."Â 

Levana smiled slightly as they continued to follow after the children.Â 

The night was deep as they walked through the Tower of the Hand. But, for some reason, the atmosphere was tense and heavy â€” it was never like this before. Levana wondered if Helaena or Ser Nandor could feel it too.Â 

Maybe she was just overthinking.Â 

"Mother?" Aemma called as Levana looked down at her daughter who was waddling at her side with Baelon following shortly after.Â 

"Yes, my beautiful?" Levana asked as Aemma thought for a while before finally speaking, "when is father coming to see us again?"Â 

Levana smiled lovingly as they neared the Queen's chambers, "in a few days, my darling."Â 

Levana would never deny Aemond of their children. He was an amazing father to them and she wouldn't imagine taking away the children from their father.Â 

Helaena opened the doors of Alicent's chambers and walked in with her children; Levana followed her lead with her own as the former began to call out the Dowager Queen's name. There was no response, instead, there was a loud bang on the door and Aemma's shriek filled the air as her younger brother was taken away from her.Â 

"Scream again and you all die," The assailant spoke as he held a knife up to Baelon's neck - Levana could only watch as Aemma ran to her side, clutching her dress. It was only then that she noticed another assailant holding Maelor from the corner of her eye.

"Who are you?" Helaena asked as the of them snickered,Â "we're debt collectors."Â 

"An eye for an eye, a son for a son."Â 

"A daughter for a daughter."Â 

Levana's eyes shot wide open as she realized who might have sent them. She walked in front of Aemma as Helaena pleaded for the life of her child.Â 

"We only want two to square things off," the other spoke with a chuckle, "won't hurt the rest of you, not one little hair."Â 

The same assailant turned to Levana with a smile, "you must be the one we're looking for, Your Grace."Â 

At this point, Levana could hear Helaena's begging, "me?"Â 

"Received the directive that it has to be your children."Â 

Levana's eyes widened as she held Aemma close to her. She could hear Ser Nandor's banging against the door but it was barred.

"It has to be yours."Â 

Helaena looked at Levana with reddened eyes as she continued to plead with the assailants, Aemma clutched her mother's skirt as she looked at her older brother.Â 

"Time's ticking, your Grace," The taller of the two chuckled, "better choose one quick or my partner might just make a wife out of your daughters."Â 

Levana took a deep breath, "who sent you?"Â 

"Doesn't matter," The one holding Maelor responded, "just make your choice."Â 

In her mind, Levana already knew who sent them. She knew very well that only one person was capable of doing such a thing.

That also meant that the choice would have to be hers to make and she would not let Helaena lose one of her children because of what her husband has done.Â 

"We seem to have one right," the man who had Baelon spoke, "the other one must be the girl behind the princess."Â 

Levana looked at her son's eyes. He was frozen in fear as a dagger was held to his neck.Â 

"Don't make this hard for you, Your Grace."Â 

The other man finally let Maelor go as he advanced towards Levana. Aemma was sobbing as she held her mother tightly.Â 

"Either we take this one or the one in your belly."Â 

Levana's eyes shot wide. Just as the assailant was about to reach for Aemma, the princess managed to give him a punch in the face. This allowed Levana to charge towards the other man but she wasn't able to reach him in time.Â 

The man had slit her son's neck.Â 

Levana watched in horror as Baelon's body fell to the ground and blood began to drench the floor. She turned back to look at Aemma and was about to make a beeline for her but the man who had just murdered her son grabbed her and forced her to her knees.Â 

"Aemma, don't let them catch you!"Â 

The younger princess was frozen in fear as Levana tried her best to budge. Helaena, on the other hand, began to untie her mother while her children cried.Â 

"Aemma!"Â 

The other man had stabbed her daughter. Levana could do nothing but scream loudly.Â 

"A daughter for a daughter," The larger of the two stated,Â "lost both a daughter and a son, gotta even out the playing field."Â 

Levana froze in terror as the assailants disappeared into the darkness. The Dowager Queen rushed to Levana, shaking her and trying to calm her down. For a moment, all Levana could do was stare at the blood that pooled from the bodies of her children - when the realization finally hit her, she began sobbing uncontrollably.Â 

Alicent wrapped her arms around Levana, trying her best to comfort her when she herself couldn't stop from screaming. Helaena, on the other hand, tried her best to console her children while watching her mother and Levana.

Levana weeped into Alicent's arms as the Queen tried her best to comfort the princess.

Ser Nandor was finally able to break the door open and guards started to search the room. Otto escorted Helaena and her children out of the room while the Dowager Queen continued to comfort Levana.

Levana was beyond consolation. She was shouting, screaming, and cursing - even after more guards had rushed into the room and Otto had ordered them to retrieve Prince Baelon and Princess Aemma's body.

For the first time in her life, Levana knew true anger and hatred. As she sobbed, she swore that she would avenge her children by any means.Â 

Even if it meant making an enemy out of her own mother.

Â 

The events that followed after that encounter were a blur for Levana who sat on her desk, writing a long letter to her mother detailing what had transpired and that their grandchildren were now dead.

She must have started a dozen letters by now but she scrapped each one.Â 

None of the letters could convey her rage and sorrow upon losing her children. She wanted to understand why it had to come to this and why couldn't they just take her in place of Lucerys.Â 

"My love?"Â 

Levana didn't turn to acknowledge the male standing behind her, instead, she chose to continue writing. Aemond knew for a fact that his wife was beyond mad and she had every right to be so.Â 

"Do you now see the consequences of your actions?"Â Levana stated as she put her quill down,Â "are you glad that you made that choice, Aemond?"Â 

Aemond took a deep breath, "I will avenge our children, Levana."Â 

"And how do you propose to do that, Aemond?" Levana asked, "our children are gone!"Â 

Aemond stood there as Levana sobbed.

"I had to watch my children die, Aemond!" Levana continued as Aemond stayed silent, "do you really love your children when you didn't even think of them when you made your choices?"Â 

"Eva..."

"Your actions are the reasons why your children have to suffer!

Aemond was starting to get angered by his wife's accusations - not because they were wrong but because he knew that, ultimately, they were what had caused this series of unfortunate events to happen.Â 

"Do you even love us the way you say you do, Aemond?"Â 

That set him off and for the first time in the years that they have been married, Aemond raised a hand to his wife.Â 

He did not hit her but the gesture was enough to make Levana stand up from her chair.

"Go ahead,"Â Levana challenged,Â "hit me, Aemond,"Â she smiled mockingly,Â "prove to me that you love me this way."Â 

"What do you want from me, Levana?" Aemond asked as he removed his eyepatch, "I lost my children too."Â 

"You do realize that you are the reason why we lost both of them, yes?" Levana asked.

"I know, Levana!" Aemond shouted in response, "you do not have to keep on tormenting me with that fact!"Â 

Levana was taken aback.Â 

"I know that I'm the reason why they came for the children in the dead of night," Aemond stated, "I know that I caused the death of our children," he added as he walked towards his wife, placing his hands on either side of her face.

"I know of the monster that I am, Levana."Â 

The female stood still as she saw the tears that were being shed by her husband, "I already lost my children," Aemond leaned his forehead against hers, "please."Â 

Levana didn't speak.

"I don't want to lose you, Levana,"Â Aemond whispered,Â "you're all that I have left."Â 

"I wish I could say the same,"Â Levana responded,Â "I'm done, Aemond."Â 

"What do you mean, Eva?"Â 

"I'm not about to lose myself because of you," Levana sighed, "you've broken too many vows and I am done with false promises."Â 

"Levanaâ€”"Â 

"You can stay in King's Landing for as long as you want but I am leaving," Levana stated firmly, "if you try to stop me or if you so much as tell the Hand or your mother that I plan to leave then I will gouge out your other eye."Â 

Aemond was taken aback. He felt the rage in his wife's words and raised his hands in defeat.Â 

"They will not hear anything from me."Â 

"Good," Levana hissed, "otherwise, Vhagar risks losing another rider."Â 

"Where will you go?"Â 

"None of your business," Levana spat, "you're so loyal to your brother and your faction that I can no longer trust you."Â 

Aemond felt his heartbreak. That was it.Â 

He lost his children.

He lost his wife.

He had nothing now.Â

[Italicized text denotes Valyrian speech]

Â 

When someone loses a husband or a wife, they become a widow or a widower.

When a child loses their parents, they become an orphan.

But what about a mother who loses a child? What do you call them?

There is no word to describe them.

There is nothing that can describe the pain and sorrow of a mother who has lost a child.

Levana stood in front of her of two pyres, while Vermithor stood behind her. The only ones in attendance were the royal family and their dragons - a few knights were present as well as the Lords of the Small Council.

Aemond stood in front of his wife, with Vhagar behind him.

"Before they were killed,"Â Levana began,Â "Aemma asked me when you would come to see us again, but I never expected this type of reunion."

Aemond remained silent. He couldn't bear to look at this wife â€” he was ashamed.

Of all their family members, the one most affected by their death was the Dowager Queen Alicent. She loved her grandchildren and the fact that she was there when they were killed only added to the grief that she shared with Levana.

"They will pay for this,"Â Levana muttered,Â "I'm going to make them pay."

"Eva," Aemond looked at her,Â "you can't go to Dragonstone alone."

"I have Vermithor,"Â Levana said,Â "they stole my children from me so I'm going to steal all their chances of ever winning this war."

"Eva, Aemond," Alicent called, "it's time."

Aemond nodded at his mother before approaching his wife and escorting her to the side. Levana looked at the pyres with an expression that no one would be able to understand.

Losing a child was a different kind of pain and suffering.

"Dracarys,"Â Levana and Aemond said in unison as their dragons unleashed flames upon their children's pyres.

Just a few days ago, Levana had to send her younger brother to the pyre and now, she had done the same for her children.

The Dowager Queen, of course, did as any grandmother would and ordered the arrest of the assailants. She commanded the City Watch to look day and night for the men who took her grandchildren and it was only a matter of time before they got caught.

"Will you still leave?"Â Aemond asked as Levana nodded,Â "if I am to save myself, I will have to leave King's Landing for greener pastures."

"I'm not stopping you,"Â Aemond responded,Â "but will you at least allow me to help you?"

"Help me with that?"Â Levana raised a brow,Â "you've done enough, Aemond."

"I can help you get to the Dragonpit, at least,"Â Aemond offered,Â "consider it my farewell."

Levana smiled slightly,Â "it's only a farewell if you don't have an intention of saying hello to me again."

Aemond chuckled, at the very least, he knew there was a slight chance that he would be welcome in his wife's life again - whenever that would be and if he survived the impending war.

"Ana," Alicent called, "we'll be returning to the palace."

Levana turned to her with a small smile and nodded before turning to Aemond, "are you not going to join them?"

"These are my last few hours with my wife and child,"Â Aemond smiled,Â "I would want to spend it with her before she leaves me."

"I will be heading west," Levana revealed, "where exactly is what I cannot tell you."

"Why will you be heading to Dragonstone?"

"To give my mother a piece of my mind," Levana stated, "Daemon as well."

Aemond turned to her with a concerned expression, "alone?"

"I'll have Vermithor," Levana turned to her dragon, "he is all I need."

The prince knew that he wouldn't be able to convince his wife to take him along nor allow him to at least be by her side at Dragonstone but at the very least, he would do her good on the vow that he made.

He was not about to betray her - not when all he's done just that and it cost them their children.

"At least take this with you," Aemond stated as he approached his wife, presenting her with a sword.

"Where did you get that?" Levana asked as her eyes widened at the realization that it was the Conqueror's sword. Aemond chuckled slightly as he placed the sword in his wife's hands, admiring her as she looked at the sword.

"I stole it from Aegon," Aemond responded, "he's not going to realize that's gone anyway."

"Why would you do this?" Levana asked, "why would you give me his sword?"

"Because you deserve it," the prince responded, "if you're going to face your mother and rain hell on her, you might as well have the proper weapon for it."

Levana looked up at him and smiled, "thank you, Aemond."

"This is the very least that I could do, my love," Aemond placed a hand on her stomach, "after all that I've done."

The princess placed a hand on her husband's cheek and pulled him close to her until their foreheads met, "please, for my sake, try your best to stay alive," she whispered as Aemond chuckled a response and wrapped an arm around his wife's waist.

"I will do more than that," Aemond promised, "but first, you need to escape from King's Landing with Vermithor," he said before placing a kiss on top of Levana's head.

"I know you will but please keep safe," the prince requested, "we still don't know how strong your mother's forces are and since you are alone, you'll be outnumbered."

Levana nodded as Vermithor bellowed. The flames on the pyres finally went out as the couples turned to them. The princess approached the pyres, watching the ashes as they began to scatter with the wind. At the very least, her children suffered a quick death - far better than what she had in mind for the assailants that took them from her.

"Eva," Aemond called as the princess turned to him with a small smile, "yes, husband?"

"I just realized it," Aemond chuckled,Â "It's your Name Day today."
